C. Student Presentations, Recognitions, and Resolutions
Subject
2. 2021-22 7th Annual SDUSD Recycling Challenge Awards
Meeting
Apr 26, 2022 - Regular Meeting, 5:00 p.m.
Type
Information

RECOMMENDATION: Recognition of the SDUSD Recycling Challenge Winners:

 

  • Elementary/K-8 School Category (100 points possible):
    • Winner: Sandburg Elementary with 80 percent waste diversion and 99 total points (Prize: $750)
    • Runner-up: Marvin Elementary with 60 percent waste diversion and 88 total points (Prize: $500)
  • Middle School Category (100 points possible):
    • Winner: Standley Middle School with 60 percent waste diversion and 92 total points (Prize: $1,000)
    • Runner-up: Knox Middle School with 60 percent waste diversion 87 total points (Prize: $750)
  • High School Category (100 points possible):
    • Winner: Patrick Henry High School with 60 percent waste diversion and 100 total points (Prize: $1,250)
    • Runner-up: Mira Mesa High School with 53 percent waste diversion and 81 total points (Prize: $1,000)
  • Most Improved Category:
    • Pacific View Leadership Elementary 50 percent waste diversion from 40 percent at the start of the school year (Prize: $250)

 

FISCAL IMPACT: None.

 

PRIOR YEAR FISCAL IMPACT: None.

 

IMPACT TO DISTRICT STAFFING: None.

 

CONSULTATION WITH BOARD ADVISORY COMMITTEE: Not applicable.

 

BACKGROUND: The board recognizes the importance of environmental sustainability for district school facilities, students, staff and community. District sustainability actions provide students with valuable learning and leadership opportunities, while helping to control district operating costs. For the second year, the district’s contract with Republic Services for districtwide waste and recyclables collection services provides an opportunity to reward schools for their commitment to sustainability through participation in the annual SDSUD Recycling Challenge.  The goal of the Challenge is to reduce waste, increase recycling, and recognize schools that encourage environmental education and stewardship, that help the district curb costs, and facilitate compliance with State and local waste diversion laws.  

 

Representatives from the district and Republic Services conducted in-person presentations of Recycling and Waste Diversion Certificates of Achievement and monetary awards to the following schools:  Sandburg and Marvin Elementary Schools, Standley and Knox Middle Schools, and Patrick Henry and Mira Mesa High Schools.  These schools represent the top two schools in each grade level category with the most total points accumulated for: highest waste diversion, lowest volume of trash generated per student, classroom and lunchtime recycling efforts, other waste reduction and diversion efforts (i.e., composting, reuse, etc.), and recycling/sustainability education, outreach, and awareness activities.  In addition, ­­­Pacific View Leadership Elementary was presented with an award for Most Improved, having increased their waste diversion from 40 percent earlier this year to 50 percent so far this school year, as well as establishing an after school Recycling Club, providing sustainability education and leadership opportunities for their students.  The Challenge ran from September 2021 through March 1, 2022.  Results were based on per capita student enrollment.

The district partners with Republic Services on a number of initiatives to increase waste reduction and recycling participation and awareness in its schools and facilities. Under the current contract, Republic Services conducts bin fullness surveys to help schools determine the most cost effective trash and recycling service for their site, assists with recycling presentations as part of education and outreach efforts, and provides recycling bins and equipment to schools to expand their recycling efforts.

 

We are pleased to congratulate and recognize our top winners on their recycling, waste diversion, and sustainability achievements!

 

[Originator/Contact:  Chris Palis, Energy/Utilities Program Supervisor, Operations Division, Office of the Chief Operations Officer, 619.260.5487, cpalis@sandi.net]

 

Video: https://drive.google.com/file/d/1NJIX6haBMQ1gS3Zikai9FnrwuRS98LJn/view?ts=624f23c5

C. Student Presentations, Recognitions, and Resolutions
Subject
3. Recognition of Employees for Years of Service (40, 30, 20, 15, 10 and 5 Years of Service)
Meeting
Apr 26, 2022 - Regular Meeting, 5:00 p.m.
Type
Information

RECOMMENDATION: As a service-providing organization, the San Diego Unified School District's employees are its most valuable resource. Today's recognition includes recognition of employees with 40, 30, 20, 15, 10 and 5 years of service. The Superintendent and the Board of Education extend their most sincere gratitude to these individuals. 

 

Today, we celebrate the milestones of 53 employees.

 

 

FISCAL IMPACT: None. 

 

PRIOR YEAR FISCAL IMPACT: None. 

 

IMPACT TO DISTRICT STAFFING: None. 

 

CONSULTATION WITH BOARD ADVISORY COMMITTEE: Not applicable.

 

BACKGROUND: Monthly recognition, meant to celebrate and acknowledge employees who have hit notable career milestones with the district. In appreciation of their commitment to San Diego Unified, the program awards a service pin for an employee's 5, 10, 15, 20, 30 and 40 year service anniversary.

 

In an effort to honor and feature as many employees as possible in the virtual celebration, all employees reaching milestones are invited to submit a self-recorded video for inclusion in the recognition portion of the board meeting. The video is also shared on the district's Employee Recognition web page. 

 

*This service recognition award is not used to calculate or verify the seniority date of an employee nor is the recognition part of the formal personnel processes that calculate the date for longevity pay. Both longevity and seniority dates are dictated by the Education Code as well as the applicable collective bargaining agreement. The date used to determine this service award is based on the individual's permanent status as an employee, temporary or hourly work is not used in the determination of the service award recognition. Service recognition awards will be awarded on a monthly basis. If you believe an error has been made, you may contact the Human Resource Service Division by emailing jobs@sandi.net.

 

Link to the April 2022 Employee Recognition Video

 

Originator/Contact: Acacia Thede, Chief Human Resources Officer, 619.725.8043, athede@sandi.net

4. Resolution in the Matter of Recognizing May 3, 2022, as Day of the Teacher and May 2-6, 2022, as Teacher Appreciation Week
Meeting
Apr 26, 2022 - Regular Meeting, 5:00 p.m.
Type
Action (Consent)
Fiscal Impact
No

RECOMMENDATION: Adopt Resolution in the Matter of Recognizing May 3, 2022, as Day of the Teacher, and May 2-6, 2022, as Teacher Appreciation Week. The Board of Education acknowledges the contributions of all dedicated teachers and encourages parents, students, and the community to publicly show their appreciation for teachers and their contributions that improve our daily lives, our communities, and our futures.

 

FISCAL IMPACT: None.

 

PRIOR YEAR FISCAL IMPACT: None.

 

IMPACT TO DISTRICT STAFFING: None.

 

CONSULTATION WITH BOARD ADVISORY COMMITTEE: Not applicable.

 

BACKGROUND: Teachers work to open students' minds to the magic of ideas, knowledge, and dreams. Teachers fill many roles, as listeners, explorers, role models, motivators, and mentors, and demonstrate their love of learning in the classroom every day. The success of more than 100,000 students in the San Diego Unified School District depends on the skills, knowledge and attitudes required while under the nurturing guidance of nearly 5,500 teachers. Teachers strive every day to support an engaging community at their schools and help create a quality school in every neighborhood. Teachers keep American democracy alive by laying the foundation of good citizenship. Teachers continue to influence us long after our school days are only memories.

 

[Originator/Contact: Board of Education Trustees, 619.725.5550, board@sandi.net]

Subject
5. Resolution in the Matter of Recognizing May 6, 2022 as School Lunch Heroes Day
Meeting
Apr 26, 2022 - Regular Meeting, 5:00 p.m.
Type
Action (Consent)
Fiscal Impact
No

RECOMMENDATION: Adopt Resolution in the Matter of Recognizing May 6, 2022 as School Lunch Heroes Day and express appreciation for the valuable and important contributions of our food and nutrition professionals who are an integral component of the districts commitment to ensuring the well-being of our students. 

 

FISCAL IMPACT: None. 

 

PRIOR YEAR FISCAL IMPACT: None. 

 

IMPACT TO DISTRICT STAFFING: None. 

 

CONSULTATION WITH BOARD ADVISORY COMMITTEE: Not applicable.

 

BACKGROUND: School Lunch Hero Day is a national celebration that has been recognized annually since 2013. This day provides an opportunity for parents, students, school staff, and the community to thank those who provide healthy meals to students each school day. School Lunch Hero Day is also a chance to highlight the difference school nutrition professionals make for every child who receives a nutritious school breakfast and lunch meal. Our food and nutrition professionals are demonstrating their sincere commitment to the welfare of our students by preparing and distributing over 150,000 meals each school day, with over 52 million meals distributed since the pandemic. Food and nutrition professionals must balance many roles and follow numerous federal, state and local regulations to ensure safe and healthy meals are available in schools. Between preparing healthy meals for students, adhering to strict nutrition standards, navigating student food allergies, and offering service with a smile, food and nutrition professionals are true heroes who always go the extra mile. 

 

[Originator/Contact: Board of Education Trustees, 619.725.5550, board@sandi.net]

F. Board Consent Agenda
Subject
6. Resolution in the Matter of Recognizing May 11, 2022, as National School Nurse Day
Meeting
Apr 26, 2022 - Regular Meeting, 5:00 p.m.
Type
Action (Consent)
Fiscal Impact
No

RECOMMENDATION: Adopt resolution in the matter of recognizing May 11, 2022, as National School Nurse Day and encourage all students,  staff, and families to celebrate and acknowledge the contributions of school nurses through celebrations including sharing on social media at #SND2022, or #schoolnurses.

 

FISCAL IMPACT: None. 

 

PRIOR YEAR FISCAL IMPACT: None. 

 

IMPACT TO DISTRICT STAFFING: None. 

 

CONSULTATION WITH BOARD ADVISORY COMMITTEE: Not applicable.

 

BACKGROUND: National School Nurse Day is a time to celebrate the specialty practice of school nursing, a dynamic profession rooted in public health. The National Association of School Nurses (NASN) and the California School Nurse Organization (CSNO) applaud the contributions school nurses make every day to advance the well-being, academic success, and life-long achievement and health of students. Credentialed school nurses are highly trained and dedicated health care and educational professionals who work closely with families, schools, and communities to develop and promote comprehensive health care programs for youth, including promoting healthy lifestyles and providing health and safety education. The San Diego Unified School District provides nursing services to support the health and wellness needs of students which is essential to their overall growth, development, and academic achievement. School nurses address both the home and community factors that impact students’ health, including complex physical and mental health conditions, students at risk for health concerns, students who are affected by societal issues such as living in poverty. To promote the good health of all students and their families, and to recognize the role of dedicated school nurses and their significant contributions to the health and achievement of students, the San Diego Unified School District adopted a Wellness Policy in 2015 which supports the Local Control and Accountability Plan (LCAP) goals. More than ever we celebrate the contributions of all health care professionals. 

 

[Originator/Contact: Board of Education Trustees, 619.725.5550, board@sandi.net]

F. Board Consent Agenda
Subject
7. Resolution in the Matter of Recognizing May 2022, as Asian Pacific Islander Heritage Month
Meeting
Apr 26, 2022 - Regular Meeting, 5:00 p.m.
Type
Action (Consent)
Fiscal Impact
No

RECOMMENDATION: Adopt Resolution in the Matter of Recognizing May 2022, as Asian Pacific Islander Heritage Month in honor of the Asian American and Pacific Islander communities in San Diego and their commitment to making this region a better place. 

 

FISCAL IMPACT: None. 

 

PRIOR YEAR FISCAL IMPACT: None. 

 

IMPACT TO DISTRICT STAFFING: None. 

 

CONSULTATION WITH BOARD ADVISORY COMMITTEE: Not applicable.

 

BACKGROUND: May is recognized as Asian Pacific American Heritage Month throughout the United States due to the enormous contributions of Asian Americans and Pacific Islanders (AAPIs) throughout the history of this great Nation. Chinese immigrants played a significant role in advancing American commerce as they laid the final ties of the transcontinental railroad at Promontory Summit, Utah in 1869, as a result of years of physical and manual labor. Over 110,000 Japanese American citizens sacrificed their opportunity to chase the American Dream and contribute to society when they were restricted as second-class citizens to living in internment camps in the 1940s. Filipino American migrant workers taught us the value of multicultural coalition building in the 1960s and 1970s, through their struggle for workers’ rights in lockstep with Chicano workers in Delano, California to form the United Farm Workers’ Movement. In the 47th year since the fall of Saigon, we must honor the resilience of the Southeast Asian community, particularly the Vietnamese, Cambodian, Thai, Laotian, Hmong, Mien, and Burmese communities, as they continue to flee conflict and relocate their lives in the United States. The Indigenous People of Melanesia, Micronesia, and Polynesia are teaching us the cultural significance of preserving and promoting one’s values and language in the context of assimilation. Korean immigrants have shown us how to overcome significant challenges as they have endured anti-immigrant policies throughout the course of American history. South Asian Americans, particularly those that are Muslim, Hindu, and Sikh, are fighting against discrimination today as they are targets of suspicion and violence. On the 57th anniversary of the Immigration Act of 1965, San Diego has significantly benefited from waves of migration that have contributed to the fabric of the region. The over 350,000 Asian Americans and Pacific Islanders in San Diego County contribute to the richness and diversity of this beautiful region. The Asian American and Pacific Islander population is the fastest growing population in the region. The ethno-linguistic diversity of Asian Americans and Pacific Islander communities in San Diego embodies the 21st century American experience. Asian Americans and Pacific Islanders in San Diego have made significant contributions as business owners, public servants, teachers, activists, health practitioners, engineers, scientists, artists and other occupations. The vibrant Asian American and Pacific Islander community will celebrate with their diverse friends, families, neighbors, classmates, colleagues, and parishioners during the month of May. The surge of anti-Asian hate crimes is testing the fabric of our nation, rather than reflecting and celebrating the countless ways the AAPI community has shaped our nation’s history. We stand in solidarity with our Asian and Asian American students, families and communities, advocating for safety, restorative justice and healing. This elected body is committed to educating the public about the history of Asian Americans and Pacific Islanders in the United States, California, and San Diego, and supports the teaching of Mandarin Chinese at Barnard Elementary, Pacific Beach Middle, and Mission Bay High Schools, Japanese at Scripps Ranch High School, and Filipino at Bell and Challenger Middle Schools, and Mira Mesa and Morse High Schools.

 

[Originator/Contact: Board of Education Trustees, 619.725.5550, board@sandi.net]

F. Board Consent Agenda
Subject
8. Resolution in the Matter of Recognizing May 2022, as National Military Appreciation Month and Recognition of 2022 Purple Star Schools
Meeting
Apr 26, 2022 - Regular Meeting, 5:00 p.m.
Type
Action (Consent)
Fiscal Impact
No

RECOMMENDATION: Adopt resolution in the matter of recognizing May 2022, as National Military Appreciation Month and recognize the 2022 Purple Star Schools: Cabrillo, Dewey, Hage, Miller, Salk, and Sessions Elementary Schools, Dana and Montgomery Middle Schools, and Canyon Hills High School.

 

FISCAL IMPACT: None. 

 

PRIOR YEAR FISCAL IMPACT: None. 

 

IMPACT TO DISTRICT STAFFING: None. 

 

CONSULTATION WITH BOARD ADVISORY COMMITTEE: Not applicable.

 

BACKGROUND: California has the largest concentration of military personnel and dependents of any other state, and San Diego County has the largest concentration of military personnel within California. There are approximately 110,700 active duty personnel and 118,300 family members, which represents over seven and a half percent of San Diego County’s total population. Military children make up a very special part of our nation’s population and nearly eight percent of students enrolled in the San Diego Unified School District are connected to military families. These brave sons and daughters stand in steadfast support of their military parents through moves and deployments. April is designated as Month of the Military Child to recognize military children for their sacrifice and bravery on the home front. May is designated as National Military Appreciation Month to encourage Americans to honor current and former members of the US Armed Forces, including those who have died in the pursuit of freedom. Six national observances are held during National Military Appreciation Month  including Loyalty Day, to reaffirm loyalty to the United States and to reflect on the proud heritage of our  American Freedom (May 1), Public Service Recognition Week, to honor men and women who serve our  nation as federal, state, county and local government employees (May 7-13), Military Spouse Appreciation Day, to recognize the important role of our military families in keeping our Armed Forces strong and our country safe (May 12), V-E Day, marking the end of World War II in Europe (May 8), Armed Forces Day, to honor everyone serving in the US Military branches (May 20), and Memorial Day, in remembrance of men and women who died while in military service (May 30). San Diego Unified is proud of its 2022 Purple Star Schools, so named by State Superintendent of Public Instruction Tony Thurmond to publicly recognize schools that are committed and equipped to meet the unique needs of military-connected students and their families, including Cabrillo, Dewey, Hage, Miller, Salk, and Sessions Elementary Schools, Dana and Montgomery Middle Schools, and Canyon Hills High School. San Diego Unified recognizes and celebrates the essential role and tremendous sacrifice of military personnel and families to our community. 

 

[Originator/Contact: Board of Education Trustees, 619.725.5550, board@sandi.net]

1. Community Advisory Committee (CAC) for Special Education Semi-Annual Report to the Board
Meeting
Apr 26, 2022 - Regular Meeting, 5:00 p.m.
Type
Information

RECOMMENDATION: Information only.  Receive report from the Community Advisory Committee for Special Education (CAC).  Chairperson Scott Soady will present the Committee's semi-annual update to the board.

 

BACKGROUND: The Community Advisory Committee for Special Education (CAC) is a district-level committee that serves in an advisory capacity to the Board of Education and special education administration on the implementation of the Special Education Local Plan. The local plan describes how the district provides services to students with exceptional needs.  Membership is comprised of parents with students who receive special education services, parents with students in general education, district staff from both special and general education, community agency representatives, and any community member who is interested in special education. Any parent of a student in the district, staff, or community member may attend and participate in CAC meetings.

Subject
4. Student Board Member Election Revisions (Patterson/Barrera)
Meeting
Apr 26, 2022 - Regular Meeting, 5:00 p.m.
Type
Action
Fiscal Impact
No

RECOMMENDATION: Approve recommendations related to student board member election as shown below. Approval of this recommendation will require subsequent revision of Board Bylaw 1035.

 

 

1. Add an additional student member to the school board commencing in the 2022-2023 school year.

2. Revise all previous regulations surrounding the Student Board Member position to specify the following:

  • -  Require that at least one student serving must be from a school with 60% or higher FRPM eligibility.

  • -  Require that no two students may actively serve from the same high school.

 

3. Establish an election process with the following guidelines:

  • -  All high school students may vote for up to two candidates: One student from a school with 60% or higher FRPM eligibility and any other student on the ballot.

  • -  Require students be offered time in their English classes to watch short candidate speeches and the opportunity to vote should they choose to do so.

 

FISCAL IMPACT: None. 

 

PRIOR YEAR FISCAL IMPACT: None. 

 

IMPACT TO DISTRICT STAFFING: None.

 

CONSULTATION WITH BOARD ADVISORY COMMITTEE: Not applicable.

 

BACKGROUND: California Education Code Section 35012 allows for student board members. A student has served on the Board of Education since 2019.

H. District Operations
Subject
1. Public Hearing and Resolution Increasing Development Impact Fees for Schools Pursuant to Education Code Section 17620; BUDGETED: N/A
Meeting
Apr 26, 2022 - Regular Meeting, 5:00 p.m.
Type
Action, Public Hearing
Fiscal Impact
No
Budgeted
No
Budget Source
Not Applicable

RECOMMENDATION: Conduct Public Hearing and Adopt Resolution Increasing Development Impact Fees for schools (Attachment 1). The revisions include adjustment for inflation of the residential project fee upward from $4.08 to $4.79 per square foot and a similar adjustment of the commercial/industrial project fee from $0.66 to $0.78 per square foot. Approval of this item by the board will cause the fees to increase 60 days following its adoption.

 

FISCAL IMPACT: None.

 

PRIOR YEAR FISCAL IMPACT: None.

 

IMPACT TO DISTRICT STAFFING: None.

 

CONSULTATION WITH BOARD ADVISORY COMMITTEE: Not applicable.

 

BACKGROUND: California Education Code Section 17620 allows the governing board of any school district to levy development impact fees against construction within the boundaries of the school district for the purpose of funding construction or reconstruction of school facilities. San Diego Unified School District (District) has collected impact fees as authorized under Education Code Section 17620 since 1987.

 

The State Allocation Board (SAB) announces the Level 1 fees typically every two years in January on the even years. On February 23, 2022, the SAB authorized an increase in the maximum Level 1 fees per square foot as follows: Up to $4.79 per square foot of assessable space of new residential construction and up to $0.78 per square foot of chargeable covered and enclosed commercial/industrial space.

 

The district is required to complete a justification study in order to continue to collect the fees. Schoolhouse Services completed a comprehensive Fees Justification Study for the District in March of 2017. Following the State Allocation Board announcement in February, 2022, Schoolhouse Services formally reviewed the Fee Justification Study and issued a Review of Fee Justification Documentation (Attachment 2) on March 7, 2022, indicating the district qualifies to continue to levy Level 1 School Impact Fees at the SAB newly authorized rate of $4.79 per square foot of residential construction and $0.78 per square foot of commercial/industrial space. This increase is due to escalating construction facility costs since the 2017 study.

 

This Board-adopted resolution for levying fees on development projects pursuant to Education Code Section 17620 is required to increase the fees as approved by the State Allocation Board. The revisions include adjustment for inflation of the residential project fee upward from $4.08 to $4.79 per square foot and a similar adjustment of the commercial/industrial project fee from $0.66 to $0.78 per square foot. Approval of this item by the Board will cause the fees to increase 60 days following its adoption.

 

Environmental Review: Education Code section 17621 specifically exempts the adoption, increase, or imposition of any fee, charge, dedication or other requirement pursuant to Education Code section 17620 from the provisions of the California Environmental Quality Act (CEQA), (Public Resources Code Section 21000 et seq.). On October 10, 2017, the Board determined that an increase in school facility fees was exempt from further environmental review under CEQA pursuant to Education Code Sections 17621 and staff filed a Notice of Exemption (NOE) with the San Diego County Recorder/Clerk on October 13, 2017 (Attachment 3). Based on the foregoing, staff has determined that the proposed increase in school facility fees is consistent with the previously approved fee increase, was fully analyzed in the referenced NOE, and no further CEQA review is required.

 

[Originator/Contact: Lee Dulgeroff, Chief, Facilities Planning and Construction, 858.637.3516, ldulgeroff@sandi.net]

H. District Operations
Subject
2. Declaration of Need for Fully Qualified Educators for 2022-23
Meeting
Apr 26, 2022 - Regular Meeting, 5:00 p.m.
Type
Action
Fiscal Impact
No
Budgeted
No

RECOMMENDATION: Approve the Declaration of Need for Fully Qualified Educators for the 2022-2023 school year.

 

FISCAL IMPACT: None. Any fees associated with the costs of a credential are paid by the educator who holds the document.

 

PRIOR YEAR FISCAL IMPACT: None.

 

IMPACT TO DISTRICT STAFFING: The Declaration of Need is a document submitted by the district on an annual basis which allows the district to retain current educators who are in the process of obtaining English Learner Authorizations or another authorization as well as to recruit and hire individuals with emergency and intern credentials.

 

CONSULTATION WITH BOARD ADVISORY COMMITTEE: Not applicable.

 

BACKGROUND: The Declaration of Need (DON) is the annual form submitted to the California Commission on Teacher Credentialing (CCTC) by county offices of education, public school districts, state-wide agencies or non­public schools or agencies. This form contains the San Diego Unified School District’s estimated number of Emergency Permits (such as Emergency CLADs and BCLADs), Limited Assignments, and Internship Credentials that will be requested during the upcoming school year. The CCTC must have a current DON on file prior to processing applications for the Emergency and Limited Assignment Permits for the upcoming school year. Upon approval, the DON will be valid for twelve months beginning July 1, 2022 and will expire on June 30, 2023. The Human Resource Services Division presents the DON in its entirety to the governing board at a regularly scheduled public meeting on an annual basis.

 

[Originator/Contact: Acacia Thede, Chief Human Resources Officer, 619.725.8043, athede@sandi.net]

4. First Amendment to Agreement with San Diego County Office of Education to Continue Providing an Outdoor Program at Camp Cuyamaca for Pacific Beach Middle School; BUDGETED: YES, CONTRIBUTIONS TO SITE FUNDS

Apr 26, 2022 - Regular Meeting, 5:00 p.m.
Type
Action (Consent)
Fiscal Impact
Yes
Dollar Amount
$82,500.00
Budgeted
Yes
Budget Source
Contributions to Sites Funds

RECOMMENDATION: Approve First Amendment to Agreement with San Diego County Office of Education to continue providing an outdoor program at Camp Cuyamaca for Pacific Beach Middle School (SC20-0684-25). Authorize the execution of any documents necessary to effectuate this service. This First Amendment extends the term of the Agreement by one year, for a revised term of December 16, 2019 through June 30, 2023, and adds funding in the amount of $82,500.00 for a new total not-to-exceed amount of $330,000.00.

 

FISCAL IMPACT: Total not-to-exceed amount: $82,500.00 is added by this First Amendment, for a new total not-to-exceed amount of $330,000.00. Budget String: 0320-96000-00-5853-1000-1110-01000-0000.

 

PRIOR YEAR FISCAL IMPACT: None.

 

IMPACT TO DISTRICT STAFFING: None. 

 

CONSULTATION WITH BOARD ADVISORY COMMITTEE: Not applicable.

 

BACKGROUND: On June 14, 2020 the board ratified an Agreement with San Diego County Office of Education to provide an outdoor program at Camp Cuyamaca for Pacific Beach Middle School students. The San Diego County Office of Education (SDCOE) Camp Cuyamaca Outdoor Program, also known as 6th Grade Camp, is certified by the California Outdoor School Association as a Residential Outdoor Science School, provided to students since 1946. The curriculum is designed to take full advantage of the next generation science standards, incorporating trail experiences and citizen scientist projects to create hands-on learning that is meaningful, memorable, and fun.  For many students, the week-long, overnight experience transforms how students feel about science and themselves as learners.

 

[Originator/Contact: Christina Casillas, Area 3 Superintendent, 619.725.5602, ccasillas2@sandi.net]

5. TalkingPoints Software Agreement for Madison High School to Provide a System for Staff to Communicate with Families through SMS Messaging in Mulitple Languages; BUDGETED: YES, LCFF INTERVENTION SUPPORT FUNDS
Meeting
Apr 26, 2022 - Regular Meeting, 5:00 p.m.
Type
Action (Consent)
Fiscal Impact
Yes
Dollar Amount
$4,520.00
Budgeted
Yes
Budget Source
LCFF Intervention Support Funds

RECOMMENDATION: Approve Agreement with TalkingPoints to provide a comprehensive site-wide license for Madison High School that provides a system for staff to communicate with families through SMS messaging in their own languages with automatic translation, and curate sets of SMS messages that staff can send to families (SW22-0755-77). Authorize the execution of any documents necessary to effectuate this Agreement. The term of this Agreement is May 1, 2022 through April 30, 2023.

 

FISCAL IMPACT: Total not-to-exceed amount: $4,250.00. Budget String: 0346-09800-00-5841-1000-1110-01000-0000.

 

PRIOR YEAR FISCAL IMPACT: None. 

 

IMPACT TO DISTRICT STAFFING: None. 

 

CONSULTATION WITH BOARD ADVISORY COMMITTEE: Not applicable.

 

BACKGROUND: TalkingPoints allows Madison High School staff to use the TalkingPoints platform to send text messages to parents/guardians who receive them in their own languages as well as English. Parents/guardians can reply in their own languages which will be translated to English for Madison staff.

 

The TalkingPoints platform allows for instant translation (machine and human-driven) both outbound and inbound, opening communication channels for parents who do not speak English.

 

TalkingPoints integrates with Clever to allow for classroom teachers to have TalkingPoints rosters.

 

This service also includes an analytic dashboard that allows administration and school governing boards (SSC, ELAC and SGT) to track engagement statistics of parents/guardians to better improve our parent involvement and engagement at Madison High School.

 

[Originator/Contact: Erin Richison, High Schools Area Superintendent, 619.725.5584, erichison@sandi.net]

Subject
7. Ratification of Agreement with Point Loma Nazarene University to Continue Providing kNOw MORE!, a California Standard Aligned, Student-Centered, Human Trafficking Awareness and Prevention Curriculum for Middle and High School Age Youth and Families in San Diego County; BUDGETED: N/A
Meeting
Apr 26, 2022 - Regular Meeting, 5:00 p.m.
Type
Action (Consent)
Fiscal Impact
No
Budgeted
No
Budget Source
Not Applicable

RECOMMENDATION: Ratify Agreement with Point Loma Nazarene University to continue providing kNOw MORE!, a California standard aligned, student-centered, human trafficking awareness and prevention curriculum for middle and high school age youth and families in San Diego County (PS22-0840-18). The term of this Agreement is April 12, 2022 through January 30, 2025.

 

FISCAL IMPACT: None.

 

PRIOR YEAR FISCAL IMPACT: None.

 

IMPACT TO DISTRICT STAFFING: None.

 

CONSULTATION WITH BOARD ADVISORY COMMITTEE: Not applicable.

 

BACKGROUND: The curriculum project was prompted in 2016, by the expressed need of district administration and the recommendation of the San Diego Advisory Council on human trafficking and the commercial sexual exploitation of children. The Councils research identified the crisis of human trafficking in San Diego County while the school district and Council prioritized the need to bring awareness and prevention to the most vulnerable age groups in San Diego schools.


On April 12, 2016, the board approved the Agreement with PLNU which provided the human trafficking peer-to-peer education as a pilot program to district high schools. Now refined, and known as the kNOw MORE! Program, the awareness and prevention curriculum is an interactive, drama-based and multimedia learning experience offered to middle and high schools. 

 

The kNOw MORE! Program serves as a California standard-aligned, student-centered, human trafficking awareness and prevention curriculum for middle and high school aged youth and families in San Diego County. It was developed with specialists in various sectors to deliver a comprehensive and engaging program to equip youth to take action for themselves and for their peers. The curriculum will provide a realistic narrative of the progression of a high school age trafficking victim and serve as an interactive device to offer youth the opportunity to play out the different choices they make to empower themselves or potential peer victims within a human trafficking scenario. The curriculum providers will work with schools and communities to adjust program format, timing, venue, and flow to make it accessible and applicable to specific and diverse populations.

 

[Originator/Contact: Wendy Ranck-Buhr, Instructional Support Officer, Leadership and Learning, 619.725.5678, wranck-buhr@sandi.net]

8. Agreement with San Diego County Office of Education to Provide the Green Machine, Splash Science Mobile Lab, and the Marine Science Floating Lab Programs for District K-12 Students; BUDGETED: YES, VARIOUS SITE IDENTIFIED FUNDS
Meeting
Apr 26, 2022 - Regular Meeting, 5:00 p.m.
Type
Action (Consent)
Fiscal Impact
Yes
Dollar Amount
$50,000.00
Budgeted
Yes
Budget Source
Various Site Identified Funds

RECOMMENDATION: Approve the Agreement with the San Diego County Office of Education to provide the Green Machine, Splash Science Mobile Lab, and the Marine Science Floating Lab program for district K-12 students (PS22-1006-18). Authorize the execution of any documents necessary to effectuate the Agreement. The term of the Agreement is April 27, 2022 through June 30, 2023.

 

FISCAL IMPACT: Total not-to-exceed amount for the term of this Agreement: $50,000.00. Various Site Identified Funds.

 

PRIOR YEAR FISCAL IMPACT: For the term of July 1, 2018 through June 30, 2021: $00.00.

 

IMPACT TO DISTRICT STAFFING: None. 

 

CONSULTATION WITH BOARD ADVISORY COMMITTEE: Not applicable.

 

BACKGROUND: This Agreement authorizes the schools to participate in the Green Machine, Splash Science Mobile Lab, and the Marine Science Floating Lab programs available for the district’s K-12 students. The pricing under this Agreement is subject to annual review by both parties.

 

The description of each program is as follows:

 

  • 1) Green Machine Lab (virtual and onsite formats)
    The Green Machine Lab has a grade-level target of K-3. This program delivers interactive lessons to help students understand why a healthy environment is important to sustainable food production. Students learn about the science of soil, alternative pest management practices, get a greater understanding of natural systems, and examine scientific concepts in real-world situations.
  • 2) Splash Science Lab (virtual and onsite formats)
    The Splash Science Lab has a grade-level target of 4-8. It is an inquiry-based program that provides students with the opportunity to learn about watershed issues. Students participate in three hands-on stations involving microscopes, water chemistry experiments, interactive watershed models, and much more.
  • 3) Krazy Kelp Forest Virtual Lab
    The Krazy Kelp Forest Lab has a grade-level target of 3-8. It is an inquiry-based program that provides students with the opportunity to learn about the species and ecosystem dynamics within a Giant Kelp forest. They become environmental scientists as they participate in three stations involving a dissection, preserved marine animals, and marine plankton.
  • 4) Curious Cephalops Virtual Lab
    The Curious Cephalopods Lab has a grade-level target of 3-5. It is an inquiry-based program that provides students with the opportunity to learn about a unique group of marine organisms. They become marine biologists as they learn about octopus, squid, cuttlefish, and nautilus by participating in three stations involving a squid dissection and
    preserved marine animals.
  • 5) Geology Rocks Virtual Lab
    The Geology Rocks Lab has a grade-level target of 6-8. It is an inquiry-based program that provides students with the opportunity to learn about the phenomena that tell the story of planet Earth’s past, present, and possible future. They become geologists by participating in four stations involving rock identification, epicenter triangulation, and plate movement calculation.
  • 6) Marine Science Floating Lab
    This program consists of half-day field trips on San Diego Bay with hands-on science instruction and materials. 

 

[Originator/Contact: Wendy Ranck-Buhr, Instructional Support Officer, Leadership and Learning, 619.725.7076, wranck-buhr@sandi.net]

9. Ratification of Agreement with The Regents of the University of California on Behalf of the University of California San Diego (UCSD) to Provide District Students with the Early Academic Outreach Program (EAOP) at District Identified School Sites; BUDGETED: N/A

RECOMMENDATION:  Ratify Agreement with the Regents of the University of California on behalf of the University of California San Diego (UCSD) to provide district students with the Early Academic Outreach Program (EAOP) at district identified school sites (PS22-0636-25).  Authorize the execution of all documents necessary to effectuate this service.  The term of this Agreement is September 1, 2021 through June 30, 2026.  

 

FISCAL IMPACT: This service is provided at no cost to the district. 

 

PRIOR YEAR FISCAL IMPACT: None. 

 

IMPACT TO DISTRICT STAFFING: None. 

 

CONSULTATION WITH BOARD ADVISORY COMMITTEE: Not applicable.

 

BACKGROUND:  The Regents of California, on behalf of the University of California San Diego (UCSD), will partner with the district in providing the Early Academic Outreach Program (EAOP) for first-generation, socio-economically disadvantaged, and English-language learning students for postsecondary education, to pursue graduate and professional school opportunities and to achieve success in the workplace.

 

This UCSD program offers free college-ready services targeted toward low-income, first-generation students who aspire to attend college immediately after high school graduation.  This program will continue providing postsecondary education and financial aid to the students while raising their academic achievement levels. 

 

District students will also receive assistance in preparing for college entrance examinations, completing college admission and financial aid applications, and enrolling in postsecondary institutions.

 

[Originator/Contact:  Nicole DeWitt, Executive Director, Leadership and Learning, 619.725.5660, ndewitt@sandi.net]

11. Third Amendment to the Agreement with Bayridge Consortium, Inc., to Continue Providing Professional Development to General and Special Education Leadership Staff to Improve Outcomes for Early Learning Inclusion; BUDGETED: YES, CRRSA ACT COVID 19 FUNDS
Meeting
Apr 26, 2022 - Regular Meeting, 5:00 p.m.
Type
Action (Consent)
Fiscal Impact
Yes
Dollar Amount
$4,000.00
Budgeted
Yes
Budget Source
CRRSA Act COVID 19 Funds

RECOMMENDATION: Approve Third Amendment to the Agreement with Bayridge Consortium, Inc., to continue providing professional development to general and special education leadership staff to improve outcomes for early learning inclusion (PS20-0152-18). Authorize the execution of any documents necessary to effectuate this Agreement. The term of this Agreement remains unchanged (April 1, 2019 through June 30, 2022).

 

FISCAL IMPACT: Total not-to-exceed amount of this third amendment: $4,000.00, for a new total-not-to-exceed amount of $166,500.00. Budget String: 5468-50580-00-5853-1000-0001-12000-0000.

 

PRIOR YEAR FISCAL IMPACT: For the period of June 30, 2021 through June 30, 2022: $27,000.00.

 

IMPACT TO DISTRICT STAFFING: None.

 

CONSULTATION WITH BOARD ADVISORY COMMITTEE: Not applicable.

 

BACKGROUND: On July 30, 2019, the board approved an Agreement with Bayridge Consortium, Inc., to provide support to the districts leadership team to develop a three-day summer institute in 2019-20, supporting principals, vice-principals, central office leaders, and central office instructional coaches to improve outcomes for students that are not within the sphere of success leading to fewer students referred to special education. Through the support of Bayridge Consortium, Inc., district staff learned more about Personalized Instruction, Collaborative Planning, Problem-Solving, Co-Teaching, Instructional Leadership, and deepened their understanding of how to provide quality instruction to all students. By gathering as a system, the intent was to ensure district staff had the tools and resources necessary to bring all students into the sphere of success.
 

On April 27, 2021, the board approved the First Amendment to the Agreement to provide support to the districts leadership team to implement eight sessions of virtual training for principals, teachers, related service providers, paraeducators, and central office staff to improve outcomes for Early Learning inclusion, integration, and mainstreaming. Through the support of Bayridge, staff learned more about personalized instruction, collaborative planning, problem-solving, co-teaching, instructional leadership, and deepened their understanding of how to provide quality instruction to all early learning students.

 

On February 22, 2022, the board approved the Second Amendment to provide professional development to the districts Early Learning Programs staff on expanding the topic of Co-Teaching in January and February 2022. The Early Learning Program teachers and administrators participated in an extended series to learn more about the structure, relationship, and instruction between a team of teachers in four two-hour virtual training sessions.  

 

This Third Amendment will provide the districts Early Learning Programs staff with four recorded sessions of the Co-Teaching extended series that was administered in January and February 2022 for use through June 1, 2022. 
 

[Originator/Contact: Sarah Ott, Executive Director, Special Education, 619.725.7650, sott@sandi.net]

RECOMMENDATION: Ratify Agreements with Nonpublic Agencies (NPA) to continue providing educational and related services to students with identified special needs as mandated by state and federal law. Authorize the execution of any documents necessary to effectuate this Agreement. The term of these Agreements is July 1, 2021 through June 30, 2022.
 

The following NPA Agreements are submitted for approval at this time:
 

1. (PS22-0362-37) Autism Experts Empowering Families and Children Together (AEFCT)
2. (PS22-0355-37) Center for Autism and Related Disorders (CARD)

3. (PS22-0356-37) Fred Finch Youth Center CARES, Inc.

4. (PS22-0357-37) New Life Physical Therapy Services, P.C. (previously known as K.I.D.S. Therapy Associates, Inc.)

5. (PS22-0358-37) San Diego County Speech Pathology Services, Inc.

6. (PS22-0359-37) San Diego Occupational Therapy, Inc.
 

Additional NPA Agreements will be submitted for ratification at a later date.

 

FISCAL IMPACT: The fiscal impact for all 2021-22 NPS and NPA agreements was previously approved at the September 14, 2021 board meeting. There is no additional fiscal impact as a result of this approval recommendation.

 

PRIOR YEAR FISCAL IMPACT: The 2020-21 fiscal impact for all NPS and NPA agreements was previously captured and approved on September 14, 2021.

 

IMPACT TO DISTRICT STAFFING: None. 

 

CONSULTATION WITH BOARD ADVISORY COMMITTEE: Not applicable.

 

BACKGROUND: On September 14, 2021, the board authorized payments to Nonpublic Schools (NPS) and Nonpublic Agencies (NPA) to continue providing special education and related services to students with exceptional needs as mandated by individual students' Individualized Education Program (IEP) and by state and federal laws during the term of these Agreements.
 

The San Diego County Office of Education (SDCOE) collaborates with the SELPA directors from each of the County SELPAs to negotiate a template agreement to be used by each, which sets the terms, conditions, and rates for agreements with CDE-certified non-public schools and agencies.
 

When all negotiations are completed, this Master Contract, along with the approved rate sheets, is distributed to all school districts in San Diego County for the creation of individual agreements with identified CDE-approved NPS/NPA student services providers. Proposed NPS/NPA agreements are then submitted to the respective school boards for approval. In compliance with a provision in each Master Contract agreement which provides for payment at the currently approved rates to the respective NPS/NPA, until such time as a successor agreement is approved, payments have been made to these providers until there is a ratification of a successor agreement. As individual Master Contracts are signed and returned to the district, they will be submitted for board approval.

 

[Originator/Contact: Sarah Ott, Executive Director, Special Education, 619.725.7650, sott@sandi.net]

RECOMMENDATION: Ratify Agreement with the Regents of the University of California to continue providing the district with the "Get Schooled on Cancer" virtual seminar series (PS22-0688-92). Authorize the execution of any documents necessary to effectuate this Agreement. The term of this Agreement is December 9, 2021 through June 30, 2023.

 

FISCAL IMPACT: None. 

 

PRIOR YEAR FISCAL IMPACT: None. 

 

IMPACT TO DISTRICT STAFFING: None. 

 

CONSULTATION WITH BOARD ADVISORY COMMITTEE: Not applicable.

 

BACKGROUND: Regents of the University of California on behalf of the University of California, San Diego Moores Cancer Center at UC San Diego Health, Community Outreach and Engagement will provide the district with the "Get Schooled on Cancer" virtual seminar series. 

 

Developed in partnership with the districts Family Engagement Department, the series will help parents and community members learn about lifestyle preventable cancers for themselves, their children, their extended families, and communities; understand the cancer screenings recommended by age/population and where to access screening; learn about the importance of genomics and genetic testing in cancer prevention, diagnosis, and treatment; learn the basics about cancer clinical trials and biobanking, as well as the importance of diverse participation; and issues of cancer survivorship.

 

[Originator/Contact: Pamela King, Program Manager, Family Engagement, Leadership and Learning, 619.886.4595, pking1@sandi.net]

RECOMMENDATION: Authorization to purchase district-adopted and supplemental instructional materials and textbooks for the 2022-23 school year, to ensure sufficient standards-aligned textbooks and/or instructional materials are available to each pupil in accordance with Education Code Section 60119, and compliance with Williams Settlement Legislation. Authorize district staff to negotiate, finalize contracts, and purchase instructional resources and materials related to this Authorization. The term of this authorization is July 1, 2022 through June 30, 2023.

 

Public Contract Code, Section 20118.3, provides that the school district may purchase supplemental textbooks, library books, educational films, audiovisual materials, test materials, workbooks, instructional computer software packages, or periodicals in any amount needed for the operation of the schools of the district without taking estimates or bids. Authorize the execution of any documents necessary to effectuate agreements under this spending authorization.

 

      • SAVVAS Envision Math 2.0 (GD-18-0857-18):  District-adopted instructional materials for mathematics at Grades K-5;
      • NGSS Science:  District-adopted and supplemental instructional materials for refurbishment of the Board-approved NGSS-aligned science program at Grades K-5; and
      • District-adopted and supplemental core subject area student materials for growth and replacement:  District-adopted instructional materials to maintain sufficiency of instructional materials and compliance with Williams legislation, including core subject area a-g, and approved supplemental instructional materials;
      • Advanced Placement Courses:  District-adopted instructional materials for schools offering Advanced Placement courses;
      • Middle College Instructional Materials:  Instructional materials and textbooks for district high school students enrolled in community college courses;
      • Dual Language and Biliteracy:  The district adopted the State-approved ELA/ELD program, Benchmark Advance, in 2019 for implementation in the 2020-21 school year.  This funding provides the adopted instructional materials in Spanish and allows expansion of the number of dual language classrooms across the district; In addition to Benchmark materials, a portion of the funds will be used to provide Dual Language Immersion schools with science or history textbooks in Spanish. Schools with language allocation plans of 100 percent, 90/10 and 80/20 will receive priority since the majority of the day is taught in Spanish.  
      • Common Core State Standards Instructional Materials:  CCSS digital resources/licenses for the districts students and teachers:
            • ST Math
            • Rosen Digital, Teen Health and Wellness
      • Special Education Instructional Materials:  Digital resources/licenses for special needs students to access News-2-You, a weekly digital newspaper cultivating literacy with current and relevant news to help individuals with special needs experience meaningful access to the world around them and Unique Learning System, an award-winning online standards-based curriculum, enabling students with meaningful access to the general education curriculum.  Funding for additional supplemental supports are also included.
      • Gate Testing: Testing materials.

 

FISCAL IMPACT:  Total not-to-exceed amount: $4,655,000.00.

IMPACT TO DISTRICT STAFFING: None. 

 

CONSULTATION WITH BOARD ADVISORY COMMITTEE: Not applicable.

 

BACKGROUND: Williams Settlement Legislation requires districts and schools to closely examine student access to textbooks and instructional materials and gather evidence to use as the basis of an annual resolution of sufficiency. Each school is required to conduct annual physical inventories of instructional materials. This inventory data is captured and analyzed by the Instructional Resources and Materials Department using the Destiny Textbook Management System. Analysis of these inventories is compared to student enrollment by the Instructional Materials Office to ensure sufficient quantities of district-adopted student instructional materials are available to meet the needs of pupils and teachers across the district. Surpluses of existing instructional materials are identified as school enrollments change and redistributed to fill shortages. Purchases are made to accommodate inventory shortages district-wide due to growth and replacement and distributed to schools in need.

 

Since 2011, the board has approved the annual adoption and purchase of instructional materials and textbooks to support the needs of district students and teachers.

 

Approved funding includes purchasing district-adopted Envision Math consumable student editions for grades K-5; funding of science kit refurbishment for the districts K-5 science adoption; funding to maintain sufficiency of instructional materials for core subject area courses and to meet the a-g graduation requirements; for district-adopted instructional materials for Advanced Placement course offerings; for district high school students enrolled in community college courses; and for district-adopted instructional materials to support dual language immersion. The minimum funding requirements identified in this authorization will maintain the instructional materials needs of pupils and teachers for these programs in the 2022-23 school year.

 

Also included is funding to support CCSS supplemental instructional materials, access to CCSS digital online resources for students and teachers, digital online resources for special needs students and teachers, and GATE testing.

 

The instructional material purchases and funding recommended in this report are identified as follows:

RECOMMENDATION: Approve Accept, Budget, and Spend Income Summary for February 2022.

 

FISCAL IMPACT: $91,277,806.00. Budget String: Various funds.

 

PRIOR YEAR FISCAL IMPACT: None. 

 

IMPACT TO DISTRICT STAFFING: None. 

 

CONSULTATION WITH BOARD ADVISORY COMMITTEE: Not applicable.

 

BACKGROUND: Actions to accept, budget, and spend income, in excess of that included in the adopted budget, are authorized by Education Code section 42602. These actions provide the means by which the Board of Education can access income which becomes available to them after they have adopted a final budget. When such added income is available and a majority of the board is in agreement as to its use, the action to accept, budget, and spend the income is a routine action. It increases the budgeted appropriations in the amount of the added income and authorizes the expenditure of that income for the purposes designated in the resolution and supporting budget.  The summary for February 2022 includes $22.2 million for the Expanded Learning Opportunities Program Grant (ELOP), $27.4 million for the Educator Effectiveness Block Grant, and $14.1 million for Local Property Taxes.   

 

[Originator/Contact: Alicia Rolfe, Controller, Finance Division, 619.725.7171, arolfe@sandi.net]

23. Second Amendment to Agreement with The Ed Ladder to Continue Providing One-On-One and Small Group Instructional Support Services to Title I Eligible Students Enrolled at the Identified Private or Nonpublic and Nonprofit School Sites on Behalf of the Private School Services Department; BUDGETED: N/A
Meeting
Apr 26, 2022 - Regular Meeting, 5:00 p.m.
Type
Action (Consent)
Fiscal Impact
No
Budgeted
No
Budget Source
Not Applicable

RECOMMENDATION: Approve Second Amendment to Agreement with The Ed Ladder to continue providing one-on-one and small group instructional support services to Title I eligible students enrolled at the identified private or nonpublic and nonprofit school sites on behalf of the Private School Services Department (PS21-0228-18). Authorize the execution of any documents necessary to effectuate this Agreement. The term of this Agreement remains September 9, 2020 through June 30, 2022.

 

FISCAL IMPACT: None.

 

PRIOR YEAR FISCAL IMPACT: Total not-to-exceed amount remains unchanged as approved by the 1st Amendment to the Agreement.

 

IMPACT TO DISTRICT STAFFING: None.

 

CONSULTATION WITH BOARD ADVISORY COMMITTEE: Not applicable.

 

BACKGROUND: On April 13, 2021 the board ratified an Agreement with The Ed Ladder to continue providing instructional support services to Title I eligible students enrolled at identified private or nonpublic and nonprofit schools participating in the Title I Program, for the period of September 9, 2020, through June 30, 2022, and for an additional total-not-to-exceed amount of $126,940.00 and a maximum total-not-to-exceed amount of $194,320.00 for the entire term of the Agreement. 

 

On October 13, 2020 the board ratified an Agreement with The Ed Ladder to provide instructional support services to Title I eligible students enrolled at identified private or nonpublic and nonprofit schools participating in the Title I Program, for the period of September 9, 2020, through June 4, 2021, and for a maximum total-not-to-exceed amount of $67,380.00.

 

This Second Amendment will continue providing one-on-one and small group instructional services for targeted Title I eligible students residing within the San Diego Unified School District boundaries attending these identified private or nonpublic and nonprofit schools participating in the Title I Program and will include two additional schools, St. Pius X and SoCal Yeshiva High School at no additional cost to the district.

 

The district is required to provide Title I, Part A services to identified private or nonpublic and nonprofit schools for eligible students enrolled at these approved schools. The district manages the funds provided to these private or nonpublic and nonprofit schools for instructional service under the Elementary and Secondary Education Act (ESEA) Title I, Part A (as reauthorized and amended by the Every Student Succeeds Acts "ESSA") funds. This service will be provided in a virtual/distance learning format or onsite, as permitted by state and local health and safety regulations for participating schools.

 

This service provides Title I eligible students enrolled at these private or nonpublic and nonprofit schools with instructional support in English/Language Arts and/or Mathematics. The identified students will participate in enhanced classes to support their academic achievement failing to meet grade-level standards. The district does not have sufficient staff available to provide these required instructional services to these schools. 

 

[Originator/Contact: Mary Johnson, Program Manager, Private School Services, Finance Division, 619.725.5611, mjohnson8@sandi.net]

25. 2022-23 Rate Schedule with Annual Direct Cost Recovery Rate Adjustments for Use of San Diego Unified-Owned Facilities by Licensed Fee-Based Child Care Providers; BUDGETED: N/A
Meeting
Apr 26, 2022 - Regular Meeting, 5:00 p.m.
Type
Action (Consent)
Fiscal Impact
No
Budgeted
No
Budget Source
Not Applicable

RECOMMENDATION: Approve the 2022-23 Rate Schedule (Attachment 1) with annual direct cost recovery rate adjustments for use of San Diego Unified (District) owned facilities by licensed fee-based child care providers, effective July 1, 2022.

 

FISCAL IMPACT: Neutral; the district will continue to collect fees based upon direct cost recovery.

 

PRIOR YEAR FISCAL IMPACT: None.

 

IMPACT TO DISTRICT STAFFING: None. 

 

CONSULTATION WITH BOARD ADVISORY COMMITTEE: Not applicable.

 

BACKGROUND: The rate schedule for licensed fee-based child care providers to utilize district property is presented to the board annually for approval, with July 1 as the effective date. Licensed fee-based child care and preschool providers operate programs at district facilities and reimburse the district for direct costs. These services offer safe havens and learning centers for district students and provide parents convenient, affordable, and reliable child care. Currently, 15 child care providers operate programs at 60 district schools, serving approximately 3,400 students.

This rate change for 2022-23, to be effective July 1, 2022, covers the following cost elements:

  • Utilities 7.6 percent increase, per district Energy/Utilities Department 
  • Custodial Services 2.9 percent increase, per district Budget Development Department
  • Restroom Supplies 3.0 percent decrease, per district Budget Development Department
  • Refuse Hauling and Disposal 2.1 percent increase, per district Operations Division
  • Administrative Charges 5.0 percent increase, per district Real Estate Department

 

Approval of this item will allow the district to annually adjust and increase, if needed, the Rate Schedule for use of district-owned facilities by licensed fee-based child care providers to achieve direct cost recovery without the need for additional Board approval.

 

[Originator/Contact:  Lee Dulgeroff, Chief, Facilities Planning and Construction, 858.637.3516, ldulgeroff@sandi.net]

The term remained unchanged.

California Government Code section 4525 allows a school district to contract with and employ any persons for the furnishing of special services if such persons are specially trained, experienced, and competent to perform the special services required.

27. Second Amendment to Joint Occupancy Agreement with The Bishops School at Sessions Elementary; BUDGETED: N/A
Meeting
Apr 26, 2022 - Regular Meeting, 5:00 p.m.
Type
Action (Consent)
Fiscal Impact
No
Budgeted
No

RECOMMENDATION: Approve Second Amendment to Joint Occupancy Agreement with The Bishop’s School (TBS) at Sessions Elementary (SV22-0134-99, Attachment 1) to include additional athletic programs as approved use.

FISCAL IMPACT: None.

PRIOR YEAR FISCAL IMPACT: None.

IMPACT TO DISTRICT STAFFING: None.

CONSULTATION WITH BOARD ADVISORY COMMITTEE: Not applicable.

BACKGROUND: On July 26, 1996, San Diego Unified and TBS entered into a Joint Occupancy Agreement (Attachment 2, Agreement) to provide improved athletic and recreational facilities on a portion of Sessions Elementary School, located at 2150 Beryl Street, San Diego, California with an initial term of 25 years, ending on August 13, 2021 and with an option to extend for an additional 41 years. TBS timely exercised this option.

 

Under the Agreement, TBS constructed improvements and facilities to the lower playground area consisting of an irrigation system, a baseball field, and backstops; and TBS was required to maintain those improvements at no cost to the district and solely at its own expense.

 

On July 27, 2021, the board approved a First Amendment to Joint Occupancy Agreement (Attachment 3) to extend the term to August 12, 2062, amend the Facilities, revise dates and hours of use with overage subject to then-current Civic Center rates, require modifications and alterations, update Notice provision to include Principal of Sessions Elementary, and clarify maintenance responsibilities of TBS.

 

The district and TBS now desire to include Boys’ and Girls’ Beach Volleyball practices and games as approved use of the Amended Facilities and clarify that only practices are allowed for varsity and junior varsity football. TBS will submit plans for district approval, as required by the Agreement, for renovations to the existing volleyball court within the Amended Facilities. Any DSA costs associated with these renovations will be reimbursed to the district by TBS. All the facilities are available for use by Sessions Elementary during school hours.

 

This Second Amendment does not increase the 502 hours of use of the Sessions field by TBS. It only provides approval for Boys’ and Girls’ Beach Volleyball practices and games to be played at Sessions Elementary as this sport was not included in the original Agreement.

 

CEQA ENVIRONMENTAL REVIEW: Approval of the Second Amendment to the existing Joint Occupancy Agreement with The Bishop’s School at Sessions Elementary is subject to the requirements of the California Environmental Quality Act (CEQA), Public Resources Code (PRC) section 21000 et. seq., and its implementing Guidelines (California Code of Regulations, Title 14, Division 6, Chapter 3, sections 15300.2 et. seq., as amended. On July 27, 2021, the board determined that the first amendment to the Joint Occupancy Agreement with The Bishop’s School at Sessions Elementary was exempt from environmental review pursuant to CEQA Guidelines Section 15301 – Existing Facilities and 15323 – Normal Operations of Facilities for Public Gatherings. The board also directed staff to file a Notice of Exemption (NOE, Attachment 4) for the project with the Recorder/Clerk of San Diego County, which was completed on July 28, 2021. Based on the foregoing, staff has determined that the proposed second amendment is consistent with the previously approved project, was fully analyzed in the referenced NOE, and no further CEQA review is required.

 

[Originator/Contact: Lee Dulgeroff, Chief, Facilities Planning and Construction, 858.637.3516, ldulgeroff@sandi.net]

Subject
28. Negotiated Agreement with FieldTurf USA, Inc., to Replace Synthetic Grass Surfacing at Muirlands Middle School; BUDGETED: YES, MEASURE YY FUNDS
Meeting
Apr 26, 2022 - Regular Meeting, 5:00 p.m.
Type
Action (Consent)
Fiscal Impact
Yes
Dollar Amount
$786,682.00
Budgeted
Yes
Budget Source
Measure YY Funds

RECOMMENDATION:  Approve negotiated Agreement with FieldTurf USA, Inc., to replace synthetic grass surfacing at Muirlands Middle School (CC22-0843-24). The term of the Agreement is April 27, 2022 through the completion of the Project.

 

FISCAL IMPACT:  Total not-to-exceed amount of $786,682.00.  Budget String: 9317-90502-00-6200-8500-0000-21500-8640.

 

PRIOR YEAR FISCAL IMPACT: None. 

 

IMPACT TO DISTRICT STAFFING: None. 

 

CONSULTATION WITH BOARD ADVISORY COMMITTEE: Not applicable.

 

BACKGROUND:  FieldTurf USA, Inc., is the sole source manufacturer, supplier, and installer of its FieldTurf systems, for which the warranty requires specialized installation from certified FieldTurf personnel.

 

Since at least 2009, FieldTurf has been the district standard for synthetic grass surfacing.  From 2006 to 2017, FieldTurf was the listed subcontractor for installing synthetic grass surfacing on four separate contracts to furnish and install synthetic grass surfacing and track, resulting in 45 fields manufactured and installed by FieldTurf USA, Inc., located at 43 school sites.  These four contracts included work other than synthetic grass surfacing, such as paving, fencing, and electrical.  Now that these 45 fields are out of warranty and need to be replaced to meet the needs of students who participate in football, baseball, softball, soccer, and other sports as well as extracurricular activities, the district has packaged the projects as furnish and replace synthetic grass surfacing, with no other work.  The district plans to enter into sole source negotiated contracts with FieldTurf USA, Inc., to replace the synthetic grass surfacing of the current 45 fields over the next six years with approximately six fields replaced per contract.   

 

The fields are listed alphabetically below but will be prioritized based on warranty or safety requirements as determined by the district:

On April 12, 2022, the district entered into a contract with FieldTurf to replace the synthetic grass surfacing at Edison and Jefferson Elementary Schools and Hoover and Scripps Ranch High Schools.  Muirlands Middle School was not included in that contract as the original intent was for Muirlands Middle School field to be included in an upcoming whole site modernization project.  The district decided to procure using this method to be able to replace the field during summer 2022, as opposed to waiting for the scheduled whole site modernization in 2024.

 

CEQA ENVIRONMENTAL REVIEW: Approval of the proposed agreement to replace synthetic grass surfacing at Muirlands Middle School is subject to the requirements of the California Environmental Quality Act (CEQA), Public Resources Code (PRC) section 21000 et. seq., and its implementing Guidelines (California Code of Regulations, Title 14, Division 6, Chapter 3, sections 15300.2 et. seq., as amended). On February 26, 2019, the board adopted a resolution certifying a Final Environmental Impact Report (FEIR) and adopting a Mitigation Monitoring and Reporting Program for the Muirlands Middle School Whole Site Modernization Project, which included modernization of the entire campus, including improved accessibility to classrooms, labs, restrooms, sports fields, and other school facilities. The board also directed staff to file a Notice of Determination (Attached) for the project with the Recorder/Clerk of San Diego County and the California State Clearinghouse, Office of Planning and Research, which was completed on February 28, 2019. Based on the foregoing, staff has determined that the proposed agreement is consistent with the previously approved project, was fully analyzed in the certified FEIR, and no further CEQA review is required.

[Originator/Contact: Lee Dulgeroff, Chief, Facilities Planning and Construction, 858.637.3516, ldulgeroff@sandi.net]
