I. Superintendent's Consent Agenda
Subject
29. Determine that the Career Technical Education (CTE) Projects at Clairemont High School, Hoover High School, and Morse High School are Exempt from the California Environmental Quality Act (CEQA) Pursuant to CEQA Guidelines Section 15301 Existing Facilities and 15314 Minor Additions to Schools; and Approve Career Technical Education Projects at Clairemont High School, Hoover High School, and Morse High School; BUDGETED: YES, MEASURE YY FUNDS
Meeting
Apr 26, 2022 - Regular Meeting, 5:00 p.m.
Type
Action (Consent)
Fiscal Impact
Yes
Dollar Amount
$50.00
Budgeted
Yes
Budget Source
Measure YY Funds

RECOMMENDATION: Determine that the Career Technical Education (CTE) Projects at Clairemont High School, Hoover High School, and Morse High School are Exempt from the California Environmental Quality Act (CEQA) Pursuant to CEQA Guidelines Section 15301 Existing Facilities and 15314 Minor Additions to Schools; and Approve Career Technical Education Projects at Clairemont High School, Hoover High School, and Morse High School.

 

 

FISCAL IMPACT: California Department of Fish and Wildlife CEQA Filing Fee: $50.00; Budget String: 9332-90502-00-6213-8500-0000-21500-8632.

 

PRIOR YEAR FISCAL IMPACT: None.

 

IMPACT TO DISTRICT STAFFING: None.

 

CONSULTATION WITH BOARD ADVISORY COMMITTEE: Not applicable.

 

BACKGROUND: The district is pursuing grant funding from the Office of Public-School Construction (OPSC) for the proposed CTE projects at Clairemont High School, Hoover High School, and Morse High School (Proposed Project). To receive grant funds, the projects must comply with the California Environmental Quality Act. Bids for the construction contract will come to the board for approval later this year. A description of each project is provided below.

Clairemont High School: The CTE project at Clairemont High School consists of converting existing classrooms and facilities in Buildings 500 and 600 into a patient care classroom and a sports medicine classroom with laboratory space. Upgrades will include new flooring, repairing existing wall surfaces, new cabinets, a new ceiling system with LED lighting, HVAC upgrades, additional electrical and data outlets, a new audiovisual system, new whiteboards, and new furniture. The existing gym restroom (Building 600) will be upgraded to meet accessibility requirements. Site improvements adjacent to the new CTE classrooms will include path-of-travel modifications from existing disabled accessible parking to the new facility. The project will not increase the existing square footage of the school, increase the total number of classrooms, or increase student enrollment or capacity.

Hoover High School CTE: Two CTE projects are proposed at Hoover High School including a Global Information Systems (GIS) Classroom and a sports medicine classroom. The GIS classroom will include upgrades to Building 500 including new office space, data and electrical upgrades, new technology equipment, standing work counters, and a collaborative work area with table seating. The sports medicine classroom will include upgrades to Building 1100 to include activity, cardio, and treatment rooms. The sports medicine classroom also includes limited interior and exterior site work for infrastructure upgrades, construction of new non-bearing wall partitions, new ceiling treatments, existing HVAC upgrades, and replacement of existing landscaping irrigation. The project will not increase the existing square footage of the school, increase the total number of classrooms, or increase student enrollment or capacity.

Morse High School CTE: The Morse High School CTE project includes the construction of a new 1,200 square foot (sf) agricultural science building which will include an agriscience lab, greenhouse, workroom, and a walk-in cooler. The greenhouse will include aeroponics, hydroponics and aquaponics facilities. Exterior site improvements include minor clearing for the building foundation, path-of-travel upgrades, landscape upgrades, new irrigation and other utilities, and accessible parking upgrades. The project will be located within an existing paved area of the campus. The project will increase the total square footage of the campus by 1,200 sf and one classroom but will not increase enrollment or capacity as it will serve existing students. 

CEQA ENVIRONMENTAL REVIEW: The approval of the Proposed Project is subject to CEQA, however, it is exempt from further environmental review under CEQA Guidelines Sections 15301 (Class 1) Existing Facilities and 15314 (Class 14) Minor Additions to Schools.

 

Class 1 consists of the operation, repair, maintenance, permitting, leasing, licensing, or minor alteration of existing public or private structures, facilities, mechanical equipment, or topographical features, involving negligible or no expansion of existing or former use. The key consideration is whether the project involves negligible or no expansion of an existing use. The Clairemont High School and Hoover High School CTE projects would be accommodated by existing classroom space and not result in the expansion of the school. The Morse High School CTE project would result in the minor expansion of the school by 1,200 sf but would not result in the expansion beyond the existing school boundaries. Furthermore, all CTE projects would serve the existing student population and are not expected to result in an increase in enrollment. Therefore, this exemption is appropriate.

 

A Class 14 exemption consists of minor additions to existing schools within existing school grounds where the addition does not increase original student capacity by more than 25 percent or ten classrooms, whichever is less. The addition of portable classrooms is included in this exemption (CEQA Guidelines 15314). The Proposed Project consists of school modernization, minor expansion, and upgrades that would not result in any increase in enrollment or classroom capacity beyond the criteria set forth in CEQA Guidelines Section 15314. Therefore, the application of a Class 14 categorical exemption is appropriate for the Proposed Project.

 

Exceptions to Use of a Categorical Exemption (CEQA Guidelines section 15300.2): The Proposed Project does not have the potential to trigger any of the exceptions identified in CEQA Guidelines 15300.2 prohibiting the use of a categorical exemption.

 

  1. Location. Classes 3, 4, 5, 6, and 11 are qualified by consideration of where the project is to be located a project that is ordinarily insignificant in its impact on the environment may in a particularly sensitive environment be significant. Therefore, these classes are considered to apply in all instances, except where the project may impact on an environmental resource of hazardous or critical concern where designated, precisely mapped, and officially adopted pursuant to law by federal, state, or local agencies.
  2. Cumulative Impact. All exemptions for these classes are inapplicable when the cumulative impact of successive projects of the same type in the same place, over time is significant.
  3. Significant Effect. A categorical exemption shall not be used for an activity where there is a reasonable possibility that the activity will have a significant effect on the environment due to unusual circumstances.
  4. Scenic Highways. A categorical exemption shall not be used for a project which may result in damage to scenic resources, including but not limited to, trees, historic buildings, rock outcroppings, or similar resources, within a highway officially designated as a state scenic highway. This does not apply to improvements that are required as mitigation by an adopted negative declaration or certified EIR.
  5. Hazardous Waste Sites. A categorical exemption shall not be used for a project located on a site that is included on any list compiled pursuant to Section 65962.5 of the Government Code.
  6. Historical Resources. A categorical exemption shall not be used for a project that may cause a substantial adverse change in the significance of a historical resource.

Environmental Review: The following provides review of the potential environmental issues associated with the Proposed Project to ensure that the above exceptions are not relevant to the project.

 

  1. Location. The Proposed Project would occur entirely within the boundaries of each existing high school campus. The Proposed Project is consistent with the existing use at each site. Furthermore, the Proposed Project would not extend into any off-site or open space areas that may be classified as an environmental resource of hazardous or critical concern. Therefore, this exception does not apply to the project.
  2. Cumulative Impact. There are no unknown future projects proposed at each project site, or in the project vicinity that, when combined with the construction timeframe of the Proposed Project, would result in a cumulatively considerable effect on the environment. Therefore, this exception does not apply to the project.
  3. Significant Effect. The Proposed Project includes modernization of existing school facilities. No work is proposed offsite that could result in impacts to sensitive vegetation or other environmentally sensitive areas as a result of the Proposed Project. As such, there is nothing unusual about existing school site or surrounding area. Furthermore, there is nothing unusual about the design of the Proposed Project that could result in a significant effect on the environment due to unusual circumstances. Therefore, there is no reasonable possibility that the Proposed Project would have a significant effect on the environment due to unusual circumstances, and this exception does not apply to the project.
  4. Scenic Highways. The Proposed Project would not result in the construction of new facilities that would directly, or indirectly, affect an officially designated scenic highway or scenic resources near a scenic highway because there are no designated scenic highways visible from of each project site. Therefore, this exception does not apply to the project.
  5. Hazardous Waste Sites. According to the California State Water Resources Control Board Geotracker database, the Hoover High School and Morse High School are not located on any list compiled pursuant to Section 65962.5 of the Government Code.

    The CTE Project at Clairemont High School is within 1,000 feet of a historic burned waste site located underneath the existing main parking area adjacent to Ute Drive, which has been classified as a potential public safety hazard by the DTSC if certain measures are not implemented prior to ground disturbing activities. On December 8, 2016, the DTSC, acting as lead agency under CEQA, prepared and filed a Notice of Exemption (NOE) for a Removal Action Workplan (RAW) for the installation of new hardscape at existing slope and planter in front parking lot of Clairemont High School adjacent to Ute Drive (SCH#: 2016128066). The purpose of the hardscape was to cap an exposed portion of the known burned waste footprint to prevent contact and inhalation of existing hazardous waste by school staff, students, and construction workers, as well as the general public.

    Project approval by DTSC also required the following measures to be implemented prior to, during, and after construction: (1) implementation of institutional controls described in an Operations and Maintenance (O&M) Agreement, which establish procedures to maintain the engineering cover/cap to ensure future activities at the site do not result in an exposure that would be considered an unacceptable risk to human health; (2) procedures for communications between district staff and regulatory agencies; (3) construction monitoring; and (4) preparation and recordation of a Land Use Covenant (LUC). Completion of the hardscape at existing slope and planter occurred at the end of March of 2020.

    Consistent with the previously approved RAW, construction of the Proposed Project, although outside the existing burned waste footprint, would require notification to the DTSC and the City of San Diego Solid Waste Local Enforcement Agency (LEA) prior to any excavation activity within 1,000 feet of the known waste footprint and to provide monitoring during construction consistent with the previously approved Community Health and Safety Plan. These conditions will be included in the Proposed Project specifications, specifically within the Earth Moving Specifications as is consistent with all projects at Clairemont High School.

    Because construction of the Proposed Project at Clairemont High School would be required to comply with the existing approved conditions outlined in the RAW, impacts associated with an existing hazardous materials condition would not be exacerbated by the construction of the Proposed Project. Therefore, this exception does not apply to the project.
  6. Historical Resources. According to the CEQA Guidelines regarding historical resources, a substantial adverse change in the significance of a historical resource amounts to a significant impact on the environment (Guidelines 15064.5(b)). Accordingly, a substantial adverse change means demolition, destruction, relocation, or alteration of the resource or its immediate surroundings resulting in the significance of the resource being materially impaired. Furthermore, according to the National Register of Historic Places (NRHP) guidelines and California Register of Historic Resources (CRHR) significance criteria, properties built at least 50 years ago must be considered for eligibility for designation in the NRHP. All three schools have facilities that were built over 50 years ago and may be considered eligible for designation in the NRHP and CRHR. Clairemont High School was evaluated as part of the 2021 District Capital Improvement Program Environmental Impact Report and found to not be eligible for listing in the NRHP and CRHR. The CTE projects at Hoover High School would occur in buildings constructed in 1976, and not eligible, individually, for listing in the NRHP and CRHR. Lastly, a Historical Resources Technical Report was prepared for the ongoing whole site modernization project for Morse High School in 2019. The Historical Resources Technical Report found that Morse High School is not eligible under any criteria for listing in the NRHP or CRHR. Therefore, this exception does not apply to the Project.

Approval of this item approves the Project as described and authorizes and directs staff to file the attached NOE with the San Diego County Recorder/Clerk.

 

[Originator/Contact: Lee Dulgeroff, Chief, Facilities Planning and Construction, 858.637.3516, ldulgeroff@sandi.net]

Determine that the License Agreement with City of San Diego for Public Access and Public Parking for Accessing Existing Trails in Rose Canyon Open Space at University City High School is Exempt from Further Environmental Review Pursuant to California Environmental Quality Act (CEQA) Guidelines Sections 15301 Existing Facilities; and Approve License Agreement with The City of San Diego for Public Access and Public Parking to Access Existing Trails in Rose Canyon Open Space within District Property Adjacent to University City High School; BUDGETED: N/A

Apr 26, 2022 - Regular Meeting, 5:00 p.m.
Type

RECOMMENDATION: Determine that the License Agreement with City of San Diego (City) for Public Access and Public Parking for Accessing Existing Trails in Rose Canyon Open Space at University City High School is Exempt from Further Environmental Review Pursuant to California Environmental Quality Act (CEQA) Guidelines Sections 15301 Existing Facilities; and Approve License Agreement with City of San Diego for public access and public parking to access existing trails in Rose Canyon Open Space located within District property adjacent to University City High School (Agreement, SV# 22-0692-99, Attachment 1). Term of the Agreement is limited to the dates listed in the Agreement.

 

FISCAL IMPACT: None.

 

PRIOR YEAR FISCAL IMPACT: None.

 

IMPACT TO DISTRICT STAFFING: None.

 

CONSULTATION WITH BOARD ADVISORY COMMITTEE: Not Applicable.

 

BACKGROUND: This Agreement provides for public parking and public access to existing trails in Rose Canyon Open Space within district property adjacent to University City High School during non-school hours. As consideration for this Agreement, City will perform brush management along the existing trails, and release district from all liability from any claims as a result of public use of the district-owned land licensed in the Agreement. Additionally, City will install public parking signage and will reimburse district for asphalt repairs and maintenance.

 

CEQA ENVIRONMENTAL REVIEW: The approval of the Proposed Project is subject to CEQA, however, it is exempt from further environmental review under CEQA Guidelines Sections 15301 (Class 1) Existing Facilities. Class 1 consists of the operation, repair, maintenance, permitting, leasing, licensing, or minor alteration of existing public or private structures, facilities, mechanical equipment, or topographical features, involving negligible or no expansion of existing or former use. The Proposed Project consists of a license agreement for parking and public access on an existing district owned property. The proposed agreement would not displace existing parking because access would only be allowed outside normal school operating hours. Additionally, the proposed agreement would not result in the construction of new parking spaces or parking related facilities. Therefore, the application of a Class 1 exemption is appropriate.

 

Exceptions to Use of a Categorical Exemption (CEQA Guidelines section 15300.2): The Proposed Project does not have the potential to trigger any of the exceptions identified in CEQA Guidelines §15300.2 prohibiting the use of a categorical exemption.

 

  1. Location. Classes 3, 4, 5, 6, and 11 are qualified by consideration of where the project is to be located – a project that is ordinarily insignificant in its impact on the environment may in a particularly sensitive environment be significant. Therefore, these classes are considered to apply in all instances, except where the project may impact on an environmental resource of hazardous or critical concern where designated, precisely mapped, and officially adopted pursuant to law by federal, state, or local agencies.
  2. Cumulative Impact. All exemptions for these classes are inapplicable when the cumulative impact of successive projects of the same type in the same place, over time is significant.
  3. Significant Effect. A categorical exemption shall not be used for an activity where there is a reasonable possibility that the activity will have a significant effect on the environment due to unusual circumstances.
  4. Scenic Highways. A categorical exemption shall not be used for a project which may result in damage to scenic resources, including but not limited to, trees, historic buildings, rock outcroppings, or similar resources, within a highway officially designated as a state scenic highway. This does not apply to improvements that are required as mitigation by an adopted negative declaration or certified EIR.
  5. Hazardous Waste Sites. A categorical exemption shall not be used for a project located on a site that is included on any list compiled pursuant to Section 65962.5 of the Government Code.
  6. Historical Resources. A categorical exemption shall not be used for a project that may cause a substantial adverse change in the significance of a historical resource.

 

 

Environmental Review: The following provides review of the potential environmental issues associated with the Proposed Project to ensure that the above exceptions are not relevant to the project.

 

  1. Location. The Proposed Project would occur entirely within the boundaries of existing district property, specifically an existing parking lot. The Proposed Project is consistent with the existing use on the project site. Furthermore, the Proposed Project would not extend into any offsite or open space areas that may be classified as an environmental resource of hazardous or critical concern. Therefore, this exception does not apply to the project.
  2. Cumulative Impact. There are no known future projects proposed at the project site or in the project vicinity that, when combined with operation of the Proposed Project, would result in a cumulatively considerable effect on the environment. Therefore, this exception does not apply to the project.
  3. Significant Effect. There is no reasonable possibility that the Proposed Project would have a significant effect on the environment due to unusual circumstances because no new construction or change in use is proposed. Therefore, this exception does not apply to the project.
  4. Scenic Highways. The Proposed Project does not require the construction of major new facilities and would not directly, or indirectly, affect an officially designated scenic highway or scenic resources near a scenic highway. Therefore, this exception does not apply to the project.
  5. Hazardous Waste Sites. The Proposed Project does not require the construction of new facilities and would not directly, or indirectly, affect an existing hazardous waste site. Therefore, this exception does not apply to the project.
  6. Historical Resources. The Proposed Project does not require the construction of new facilities and would not directly, or indirectly, affect an existing historic or prehistoric resource. Therefore, this exception does not apply to the project.

 

Approval of this item approves the Proposed Project as described, authorizes and directs staff to file the attached Notice of Exemption with the San Diego County Recorder/Clerk (Attachment 2), and approves the license agreement with City of San Diego for public access and public parking for accessing existing trails in Rose Canyon Open Space at University City High School.

 

[Originator/Contact: Lee Dulgeroff, Chief, Facilities Planning and Construction, 858.637.3516, ldulgeroff@sandi.net]

31. Agreement with Genuine Parts Co. dba NAPA Auto Parts to Continue Providing Non OEM Automotive Repair Parts; BUDGETED: YES, PUPIL TRANSPORTATION, FLEET MAINTENANCE FUNDS
Meeting
Apr 26, 2022 - Regular Meeting, 5:00 p.m.
Type
Action (Consent)
Fiscal Impact
Yes
Dollar Amount
$2,266,044.57
Budgeted
Yes
Budget Source
Pupil Transportation, Fleet Maintenance Funds

RECOMMENDATION: Approve Agreement with Genuine Parts Company dba NAPA Auto Parts (GD22-0504-03), to continue providing non OEM automotive repair parts and supplies. Authorize the execution of any documents necessary to effectuate these Agreements. The term of the Agreements is April 27, 2022 through March 21, 2025.

 

FISCAL IMPACT: Total not-to-exceed amount: $2,266,044.57. Budget String: 5650-09971-00-4316-3600-0000-01000-7791.         

 

PRIOR YEAR FISCAL IMPACT: For the period of July 1, 2020 through June 1, 2021: $65,815.05.

 

IMPACT TO DISTRICT STAFFING: None. 

 

CONSULTATION WITH BOARD ADVISORY COMMITTEE: Not applicable.

 

BACKGROUND: The district requires automotive repair parts and supplies on an as-needed basis to support the proper maintenance and operation of all district vehicles and the safety of all students. Public Contract Code 20111 requires school districts to advertise for competitive bids for goods over $99,100.00. 


The district advertised Bid No. GD22-0504-03 for two consecutive weeks.  Vendors submitted bids based on line item and lot. On February 10, 2022, at 2:00 pm the bid opening was conducted via Planet Bids. The district received bids from three vendors: Advanced Auto Parts, Genuine dba NAPA Auto Parts, and Romaine Electric.  After evaluation of the bids Genuine Parts dba NAPA Auto Parts has been deemed the lowest responsive bidder.

 

Advanced Auto Parts and Romaine Electric were deemed to be non-responsive for not bidding all three years. 

 

Therefore, the Agreement will be awarded to Genuine Parts dba NAPA Auto Parts based on the lowest price submitted. 

 

[Originator/Contact: Gene Robinson, Director, Transportation and Distribution Services, Office of Operations Support Officer, 858.496.8710, grobinson@sandi.net]

I. Superintendent's Consent Agenda
Subject
32. Determine that the Project to Remove and Replace Electrical Service Equipment at Hickman Elementary School (ES) and Sandburg ES is Exempt Pursuant to California Environmental Quality Act (CEQA) Guidelines Section 15301 Existing Facilities; and Agreement with Sun Diego Electric to Remove and Replace Electrical Service at Hickman ES and Sandburg ES; BUDGETED: YES, PPO CAPITAL PROJECTS RESOURCE FUNDS
Meeting
Apr 26, 2022 - Regular Meeting, 5:00 p.m.
Type
Action (Consent)
Fiscal Impact
Yes
Dollar Amount
$477,895.79
Budgeted
Yes
Budget Source
PPO Capital Projects Resource Funds

RECOMMENDATIONS: Determine that the project to remove and replace electrical service equipment at Hickman Elementary School (ES) and Sandburg ES is Exempt Pursuant to California Environmental Quality Act (CEQA) Guidelines Section 15301 Existing Facilities; and Approve Agreement with Sun Diego Electric to remove and replace electrical service at Hickman ES and Sandburg ES (CP22-0764-52). The term of the Agreement is April 26, 2022 through the completion of the Project.

 

 

FISCAL IMPACT: Total not-to-exceed amount of $477,895.79 (Contract Amount). Budget String: 9609-81504-00-5711-8100-0000-01000-0000.

 

PRIOR YEAR FISCAL IMPACT: None.

 

IMPACT TO DISTRICT STAFFING: None.

 

CONSULTATION WITH BOARD ADVISORY COMMITTEE: Not applicable.

 

BACKGROUND: This project consists of removing and replacing the main electrical service at Hickman Elementary School and Sandburg Elementary School.

 

Pursuant to Public Contract Code section 20111(b), the district must publicly competitively bid any public project involving an expenditure of $15,000.00 or more. The notice calling for bids was published once a week for two successive weeks in accordance with Public Contract Code section 20112. Bids were due and opened on March 16, 2022. The district received a total of seven bids from G.A. Abell, Inc., dba Precision Electric Company; GA Technical Services, Inc.; National Electric Works, Inc.; Polar Electric Company; Rod Fuller Electric Corporation, dba Fuller Electric; Saturn Electric, Inc.; and Sun Diego Electric. After evaluating the bids, staff determined Sun Diego Electric to be the lowest responsive and responsible bidder.

 

Additionally, consistent with the May 10, 2011, board-approved resolution in support of service-disabled veteran-owned businesses (SDVOB) and disabled veteran business enterprises (DVBE) which established a three percent required participation of DVBEs for all district construction contracting opportunities. The recommended contractor, Sun Diego Electric, submitted a 4.91 percent DVBE participation in its bid.

 

CEQA ENVIRONMENTAL REVIEW: The approval of the Proposed Project is subject to CEQA however, it is exempt from further environmental review under CEQA Guidelines sections 15301(a) (Class 1) Existing Facilities. Class 1 consists of the operation, repair, maintenance, permitting, leasing, licensing, or minor alteration of existing public or private structures, facilities, mechanical equipment, or topographical features, involving negligible or no expansion of existing or former use. Examples include but are not limited to electrical conveyances. The Proposed Project would include the installation of new electrical equipment to support existing school facilities. Therefore, the application of a Class 1 Categorical Exemption is appropriate for the Proposed Project.

 

Exceptions to Use of a Categorical Exemption (CEQA Guidelines Section 15300.2): The Proposed Project does not have the potential to trigger any of the exceptions identified in CEQA Guidelines section 15300.2, and summarized below, prohibiting the use of a categorical exemption.

 

  1. Location. Classes 1, 2, 3, and 11 are qualified by consideration of where the project is to be located a project that is ordinarily insignificant in its impact on the environment may in a particularly sensitive environment be significant. Therefore, these classes are considered to apply in all instances, except where the project may impact on an environmental resource of hazardous or critical concern where designated, precisely mapped, and officially adopted pursuant to law by federal, state, or local agencies.
  2. Cumulative Impact. All exemptions for these classes are inapplicable when the cumulative impact of successive projects of the same type in the same place, over time is significant.
  3. Significant Effect. A categorical exemption shall not be used for an activity where there is a reasonable possibility that the activity will have a significant effect on the environment due to unusual circumstances.
  4. Scenic Highways. A categorical exemption shall not be used for a project which may result in damage to scenic resources, including but not limited to, trees, historic buildings, rock outcroppings, or similar resources, within a highway officially designated as a state scenic highway. This does not apply to improvements that are required as mitigation by an adopted negative declaration or certified EIR.
  5. Hazardous Waste Sites. A categorical exemption shall not be used for a project located on a site that is included on any list compiled pursuant to Section 65962.5 of the Government Code.
  6. Historical Resources. A categorical exemption shall not be used for a project that may cause a substantial adverse change in the significance of a historical resource.

Environmental Review: The following provides review of the potential environmental issues associated with the Proposed Project to ensure that the above exceptions are not relevant to the project.

 

  1. Location. The Proposed Project would occur entirely within the boundaries of existing school sites. Installation of electrical equipment is consistent with existing uses at each of the existing school sites. Generally, the surrounding land uses at each site consist of residential housing and the Proposed Project would not extend into any offsite or open space areas. Therefore, this exception does not apply to the project.
  2. Cumulative Impact. There are no known future projects proposed at each school site or in the project vicinity that, when combined with the construction of the Proposed Project, would result in a cumulatively considerable effect on the environment. Once the Proposed Project has been constructed, school operations at each site would remain unchanged compared with existing conditions. Therefore, this exception does not apply to the project. Therefore, this exception does not apply to the project.
  3. Significant Effect. The Proposed Project includes the installation electrical equipment at existing school sites. No work is proposed offsite that could result in impacts to sensitive vegetation or other environmentally sensitive areas because of the Proposed Project. As such, there is nothing unusual about each of the school sites or surrounding area. Furthermore, there is nothing unusual about the design of the Proposed Project that could result in a significant effect on the environment due to unusual circumstances. Therefore, there is no reasonable possibility that the Proposed Project would have a significant effect on the environment due to unusual circumstances, and this exception does not apply to the project.
  4. Scenic Highways. The Proposed Project would not result in the demolition of existing structures or the construction of new facilities that would directly or indirectly affect an officially designated scenic highway or scenic resources near a scenic highway. Therefore, this exception does not apply to the project.
  5. Hazardous Waste Sites. According to the California State Water Resources Control Board Geotracker database, none of the school sites are included on any list compiled pursuant to Section 65962.5 of the Government Code. Therefore, this exception does not apply to the project.
  6. Historical Resources. According to the CEQA Guidelines regarding historical resources, a substantial adverse change in the significance of a historical resource amounts to a significant impact on the environment (Guidelines 15064.5(b)). Accordingly, a substantial adverse change means demolition, destruction, relocation, or alteration of the resource or its immediate surroundings resulting in the significance of the resource being materially impaired. Because the Proposed Project does not require the demolition of existing historical era buildings or structures, the significance of a potentially historical resource will not be materially impaired, and no substantial adverse changes to the significance of a historical resource or significant impacts to the environment at each of the existing school sites is anticipated. Additionally, the likelihood of impacting either prehistoric or historic archeological resources is negligible for the current undertaking due because grading and trenching into non-native soils is not proposed. This exception does not apply to the project.

Approval of this item approves the Proposed Project as described and authorizes and directs staff to file the attached Notice of Exemption with the San Diego County Recorder/Clerk, and approves the agreement with Sun Diego Electric to Remove and Replace Electrical Service at Hickman ES and Sandburg ES.

 

[Originator/Contact: John Hensley, Director, Physical Plant Operations, Office of the Chief Operations Officer, 858.627.7151, jhensley@sandi.net]

33. Determine that the Re-Roof Project at Roosevelt Middle School is Exempt from Further Environmental Review Pursuant to California Environmental Quality Act (CEQA) Guidelines Sections 15301 Existing Facilities; Agreement with A. Preman Roofing, Inc., to Re-Roof 700 Building at Roosevelt Middle School; BUDGETED: YES, PPO CAPITAL PROJECTS RESOURCE FUNDS
Meeting
Apr 26, 2022 - Regular Meeting, 5:00 p.m.
Type
Action (Consent)
Fiscal Impact
Yes
Dollar Amount
$194,095.00
Budgeted
Yes
Budget Source
PPO Capital Projects Resource Funds

RECOMMENDATION: Determine that the Re-Roof Project at Roosevelt Middle School is Exempt from Further Environmental Review Pursuant to California Environmental Quality Act (CEQA) Guidelines Sections 15301 Existing Facilities; Approve agreement with A. Preman Roofing, inc. to re-roof 700 Building at Roosevelt Middle School (CP22-0844-24). The term of the Agreement is April 27, 2022, through the completion of the Project.

 

FISCAL IMPACT:  Total not-to-exceed amount of $194,095.00. Budget String: 9609-81504-00-5711-8100-0000-01000-0000.

 

PRIOR YEAR FISCAL IMPACT:  None. 

 

IMPACT TO DISTRICT STAFFING: None.

 

CONSULTATION WITH BOARD ADVISORY COMMITTEE: Not applicable.

 

BACKGROUND:  This project consists of removal of existing roof system and installing a new built-up roof systems on all levels of the 700 building at Roosevelt Middle School.

 

Pursuant to Public Contract Code section 20111(b), the district must publicly competitively bid any public project involving an expenditure of $15,000.00 or more. The notice calling for bids was published once a week for two successive weeks in accordance with Public Contract Code section 20112. Bids were due and opened on March 31, 2022. The district received a total of five bids from A Good Roofer, Inc., A. Preman Roofing, Inc., Chambers, Inc., dba Roof Construction, Commercial Waterproofing Systems, Inc., dba ERC Roofing and Waterproofing, and Sylvester Roofing Company, Inc. After evaluating the bids, staff determined A. Preman Roofing, Inc., to be the lowest responsive and responsible bidder.

 

Additionally, consistent with the May 10, 2011, board-approved resolution in support of service-disabled veteran-owned businesses (SDVOB) and disabled veteran business enterprises (DVBE) which established a three percent required participation of DVBEs for all district construction contracting opportunities. The recommended contractor, A. Preman Roofing, Inc., submitted a six percent DVBE participation in its bid.

 

CEQA ENVIRONMENTAL REVIEW: The proposed activity is a project subject to the California Environmental Quality Act (CEQA), however, it is exempt from further environmental review under CEQA Guidelines Sections. Class 1 consists of the operation, repair, maintenance, permitting, leasing, licensing, or minor alteration of existing public or private structures, facilities, mechanical equipment, or topographical features, involving negligible or no expansion of existing or former use. (CEQA Guidelines 15301]). The Proposed Project involves roof repairs to an existing school district facility. Therefore, the application of a Class 1 categorical exemption is appropriate for the Project.

 

Exceptions to Use of a Categorical Exemption (CEQA Guidelines Section 15300.2): Section 15300.2 of the State CEQA Guidelines specifies several exceptions to the use of a categorical exemption.

  • Location. Classes 3, 4, 5, 6, and 11 are qualified by consideration of where the Project is to be located a Project that is ordinarily insignificant in its impact on the environment may, in a particularly sensitive environment, be significant, therefore, these classes are considered to apply in all instances, except where the Project may impact on an environmental resource of hazardous or critical concern where designated, precisely mapped, and officially adopted pursuant to law by federal, state, or local agencies. The Proposed Project does not fall within this class of exemption. Therefore, this exception does not apply to the project.
  • Cumulative Impact. All exemptions for these classes are inapplicable when the cumulative impact of successive projects of the same type in the same place, over time is significant. The Proposed Project consists of repairs to existing facilities and would not result in cumulative construction impacts because no ongoing projects would occur at the same time as the construction of the Proposed Project. Operational cumulative impacts would not occur because no operational changes are proposed. Therefore, this exception does not apply to the project.
  • Significant Effect. A categorical exemption shall not be used for an activity where there is a reasonable possibility that the activity will have a significant effect on the environment due to unusual circumstances. The Proposed Project consists of repairs to existing facilities where no changes in use would occur. Therefore, this exception does not apply to the project.
  • Scenic Highways. A categorical exemption shall not be used for a project which may result in damage to scenic resources, including but not limited to, trees, historic buildings, rock outcroppings, or similar resources, within a highway officially designated as a state scenic highway. There are no exterior physical improvements associated with the Proposed Project that would result in new impacts to scenic highways. Therefore, this exception does not apply to the project.
  • Hazardous Waste Sites. A categorical exemption shall not be used for a project located on a site that is included on any list compiled pursuant to Section 65962.5 of the Government Code. There are no physical improvements associated with the Proposed Project that would result in new hazardous materials impacts. Therefore, this exception does not apply to the project.
  • Historical Resources. A categorical exemption shall not be used for a project that may cause a substantial adverse change in the significance of a historical resource. There are no physical improvements associated with the Proposed Project that would result in impacts to existing historical resources. While Roosevelt Elementary has historic era buildings, a historical resources report for the Multi-Campus HVAC Project (SCH# 2019011018) prepared by PaleoWest Archaeology in 2018, determined that no historic building are present on site and the subject building 700 is not eligible as a historic resource. Therefore, this exception does not apply to the project.

Approval of this item approves the Proposed Project as described, authorizes and directs staff to file the attached Notice of Exemption with the San Diego County Recorder/Clerk, and approves the agreement as described above.

 

[Originator/Contact: John Hensley, Director, Physical Plant Operations, Office of the Chief Operations Officer, 858.627.7151, jhensley@sandi.net]

RECOMMENDATION: Authorization to approve First Amendment with Waxie Sanitary Supply (GD21-0810-82) to increase spending to the original Agreement and extend the term of the agreement to expire on March 22, 2024 to allow for the full three years to continue providing janitorial supplies and equipment. 

 

FISCAL IMPACT: Additional spending authorization of $396,466.51, for a new total not-to-exceed amount of $5,605,831.81. Budget String: 5600-00031-00-4302-8100-0000-01000-0000.

IMPACT TO DISTRICT STAFFING: None. 

 

CONSULTATION WITH BOARD ADVISORY COMMITTEE: Not applicable.

 

BACKGROUND: Strategic Sourcing and Contracts advertised a one-year term Bid No. GD22-0810-30 on March 3, 2022, for two weeks to competitively solicit bids for additional Janitorial Supplies and Equipment. On March 17, 2022, at 1:00 p.m., the public bid opening was conducted via PlanetBids. The district received bids from the following firms: Mega Gloves, Staples, Uweport, LLC, Signal Hill Auto Enterprises, Inc., Brady Industries of California, LLC, Home Depot Pro, American Sanitary Supply, Waxie Sanitary Supply, MSC Industrial Supply and American Safety Sales.

We are asking that the increase in spending be added to the original contract (GD21-0810-82) due to the district's internal EDX system not being able to separate the items between the two contracts for the same supplier.

 

On March 23, 2021, the board approved the Agreement with Waxie Sanitary Supply (GD21-0810-82) to continue providing Janitorial Supplies and Equipment for the term of March 24, 2021 through March 22, 2023.

36. Agreement with Mountain Materials, Inc., to Provide Decomposed Granite, Sand and Rock; BUDGETED: YES, ONGOING AND MAJOR MAINTENANCE FUNDS
Meeting
Apr 26, 2022 - Regular Meeting, 5:00 p.m.
Type
Action (Consent)
Fiscal Impact
Yes
Dollar Amount
$511,300.69
Budgeted
Yes
Budget Source
Ongoing and Major Maintenance Funds

RECOMMENDATION: Approve Agreement with Mountain Materials, Inc., to provide decomposed granite, sand and rock (GD22-0802-30). Authorize the execution of any documents necessary to effectuate this Agreement. The term of this Agreement is April 27, 2022, through April 26, 2025.

 

FISCAL IMPACT: Total not-to-exceed amount of $511,300.69, during the three-year term of the Agreement. Budget String: 5686-81500-00-4315-8100-0000-01000-0000.

 

PRIOR YEAR FISCAL IMPACT: For the period of March 15, 2021, through March 14, 2022: $70,000.00.

 

IMPACT TO DISTRICT STAFFING: None. 

 

CONSULTATION WITH BOARD ADVISORY COMMITTEE: Not applicable.

 

BACKGROUND: The district requires decomposed granite, masonry sand, rock, and topsoil on an ongoing as-needed basis. On March 3, 2022, the district advertised Bid No. GD22-0802-30, for two weeks to competitively solicit bids for decomposed granite, sand and rock. On March 17, 2022, at 1:00 p.m., the public bid opening was conducted via PlanetBids. The district received bids from the following firms: Mountain Materials, Inc., and Green Dream International, LLC. After evaluation of all bids received, Mountain Materials, Inc., was the lower responsive bidder.

 

The Physical Plant Operations Department manages the overall maintenance of the district's grounds and building systems. The decomposed granite is used to resurface fields and playgrounds. Plaster sand is used to backfill excavated trench lines for water and sewer repair and mixing concrete. Masonry sand is used to fill playground sandboxes. The district uses 'just in time' deliveries as well as bunkers to stock decomposed granite and rock.

 

[Originator/Contact: John Hensley, Director, Physical Plant Operations, Office of the Chief of Operations Officer, 858.627.7127; jhensley@sandi.net]

Subject
40. Agreement with E-Fun, LLC, dba Pedego San Diego to Purchase Electric Bikes for the Electric Bike Lending Library for Lincoln High School Staff and Students Under the Clean Mobility in Schools Pilot Project for the California Air Resources Board (CARB) Grant; BUDGETED: YES, CLEAN MOBILITY IN SCHOOL GRANT FUNDS
Meeting
Apr 26, 2022 - Regular Meeting, 5:00 p.m.
Type
Action (Consent)
Fiscal Impact
Yes
Dollar Amount
$75,000.00
Budgeted
Yes
Budget Source
Clean Mobility in School Grant Funds

RECOMMENDATION: Approve Agreement with E-Fun, LLC, dba Pedego San Diego to purchase electric bikes for the Electric Bike Lending Library for Lincoln High School staff and students under the Clean Mobility in Schools Pilot Project for the California Air Resources Board (CARB) Grant (PS22-0770-11). The term of this Agreement is April 27, 2022 through April 26, 2024.

 

FISCAL IMPACT: Total not-to-exceed amount: $75,000.00. Budget String: 5650-78555-00-6495-3600-0000-01000-7790.

 

PRIOR YEAR FISCAL IMPACT: None.

 

IMPACT TO DISTRICT STAFFING: None.

 

CONSULTATION WITH BOARD ADVISORY COMMITTEE: Not applicable.

 

BACKGROUND: On February 11, 2020, the board approved a resolution to authorize an agreement to accept grant funds from the California Air Resources Board (CARB) for the Clean Mobility in Schools Pilot Project to reduce the districts carbon footprint by replacing existing diesel and/or gasoline-powered mobility vehicles and other equipment with electric vehicles (including electric bikes), with the objective to reduce greenhouse gas (GHG) emissions from the schools in the Lincoln High School cluster.

 

As the district is developing a strategy to achieve zero-net-energy by 2030, this Agreement will lend itself to be the catalyst. The Lincoln High School cluster is identified within a disadvantaged community near the Port of San Diego, an area within San Diego County's worst air quality. Purchasing electric bikes (e-bikes) for use within the established disadvantaged area will aid in cultivating mobility and support the adaption of improved air quality for children, families, staff, and the community. The reduction of GHG emissions from the disadvantaged community aids California's ambitious goals of improving air quality near San Diego's port.

 

This Agreement is in conjunction with other Clean Mobility in Schools Pilot Project Agreements through the CARB grant (Calstart PS20-1267-40 and Circulate San Diego PS21-0536-40) and will provide Lincoln High School staff and grade 12 students with an Electric Bike Lending Library to use during the school year.  Circulate San Diego will provide support to the e-bikes program, as well as assist with the selection of program participants (district staff and grade 12 students) by conducting surveys. Calstart will collect data from the e-bikes and provide information to help with the overarching goal of developing a functional transportation system to facilitate GHG emissions reductions and support communities through public health, environmental, and economic improvement.

 

The purchase of electric bikes will assist the district in implementing an e-mobility program that will serve as an example of best practices for school districts across the state and ultimately across the U.S.

 

[Originator/Contact: Gene Robinson, Director, Transportation and Distribution Services, Office of the Operations Support Officer, 858.496.8710, grobinson@sandi.net]

BACKGROUND:  These transactions are submitted to the board for review pursuant to Education Code sections 17604 and 17605 and under its delegation of authority to the district Strategic Sourcing and Contracts Officer.  To allow for efficiency in the administration of a large urban school district, California Education Code section 17605 specifically allows a school district to delegate limited purchasing power, i.e., for purchases no greater than $99,100.00 (for the year 2022) for supplies, materials, apparatus, equipment, non-construction services not greater than $99,100.00, and construction services less than $15,000.00.  For this reason, these types of transactions must be reviewed by the board within 60 days of the date of the transaction under Education Code section 17605.  Pursuant to the authority delegated to the district Strategic Sourcing and Contracts Officer on June 22, 2021, these purchase orders have been released to the respective vendors and are being submitted for review by the board at this time.  Additionally, the attached agreements were signed pursuant tot he delegation of authority and, as required by Education Code section 17604, must be approved or ratified by the Board of Education.  The district has met the requirements of Education Code sections 17604 and 17605 with this process of reporting out the specified purchase orders under $99,100.00 (for the year 2022) that are not associated with any previously-approved board contracts and the ratification of contracts signed under delegation of authority.

Subject
48. Agreement with GreenPower Motor Company for the Purchase of Two Electric Vehicles per the California Air Resources Board (CARB) Grant; BUDGETED: YES, CLEAN MOBILITY IN SCHOOL GRANT FUNDS
Meeting
Apr 26, 2022 - Regular Meeting, 5:00 p.m.
Type
Action (Consent)
Fiscal Impact
Yes
Dollar Amount
$354,822.91
Budgeted
Yes
Budget Source
Clean Mobility in School Grant Funds

RECOMMENDATION: Approve Agreement with GreenPower Motor Company for the purchase of two electric vehicles [one electric food delivery truck and one passenger van] lots 1 and 4 per the California Air Resources Board (CARB) Grant (GD22-1065-03). Reject California Cart Builder, LLC, as non-responsive for lots 2 and 3.  Authorize the execution of any documents necessary to effectuate these Agreements. The term of this Agreement is April 27, 2022 through Jun 30, 2022.

 

FISCAL IMPACT: Total not-to-exceed amounts: $354,822.91. Budget String: 5650-78555-00-6495-3600-0000-01000-7790.

 

PRIOR YEAR FISCAL IMPACT: None. 

 

IMPACT TO DISTRICT STAFFING: None. 

 

CONSULTATION WITH BOARD ADVISORY COMMITTEE: Not applicable.

 

BACKGROUND: On February 11, 2020, the board approved a resolution to authorize an agreement to accept grant funds from the California Air Resources Board (CARB) for the Clean Mobility in Schools Pilot Grant #G18-CMIS-02. 

 

On January 20, 2022 and January 27, 2022, the district advertised to purchase four electric vehicles [one each of an electric food delivery truck, electric food truck, electric mobile command truck, and electric passenger van] to replace aged units that are having difficulty meeting the state’s current smog emission requirements.

 

On February 17, 2022, the district received bids from GreenPower Motor Company and California Cart Builder, LLC. GreenPower Motor Company is recommended for the purchase of two of the electric vehicles [one electric food delivery truck and one passenger van] lines 1 and 4 of the bid. 

 

The district is rejecting the bid from California Cart Builder, LLC, as non-responsive for lots 2 and 3 as they did not meet the terms and conditions of bid. The district may rebid these two lines at a later date.

This purchase will help ensure that the district implements an e-mobility program that will serve as an example of best practices to school districts across the state, and ultimately across the U.S.

 

[Originator/Contact: Gene Robinson, Director, Transportation and Distribution Services, Office of the Operations Support Officer, 858.496.8710, grobinson@sandi.net]

Subject
49. Agreement with the Regents of the University of California to Provide the District with Tutoring Support for Students Identified as Refugee Newcomer Youth and Youth Experiencing Homelessness; BUDGETED: YES, AMERICAN RESCUE PLAN (ARP) EDUCATION OF HOMELESS CHILDREN AND YOUTH, MCKINNEY-VENTO, REFUGEE SCHOOL IMPACT (RSI) GRANT FUNDS
Meeting
Apr 26, 2022 - Regular Meeting, 5:00 p.m.
Type
Action (Consent)
Fiscal Impact
Yes
Dollar Amount
$306,440.00
Budgeted
Yes
Budget Source
American Rescue Plan (ARP) Education of Homeless Children and Youth, McKinney-Vento, Refugee School Impact (RSI) Grant Funds

RECOMMENDATION: Approve Agreement with the Regents of the University of California to provide the district with tutoring support for students identified as refugee newcomer youth and youth experiencing homelessness (SV22-0628-92). Authorize the execution of any documents necessary to effectuate this Agreement. The term of this Agreement is May 1, 2022 through December 31, 2024. For the time period of October 1, 2024 through December 31, 2024, as applicable, budget string(s) will be determined at a later date, contingent upon available district funding. 

 

FISCAL IMPACT: Total not-to-exceed amount: $306,440.00.

 

Budget Strings:

5660-58700-00-5100-2100-0000-01000-0000: Refugee School Impact (RSI)

5660-56320-00-5100-2100-0000-01000-0000: American Rescue Plan, Education of Homeless Children and Youth I (ARP-EHCY I)

5660-56340-00-5100-2100-0000-01000-0000: American Rescue Plan, Education of Homeless Children and Youth II (ARP-EHCY II)

5660-56300-00-5100-2100-0000-01000-0000: Education of Homeless Children and Youth (EHCY)- McKinney-Vento 

 

PRIOR YEAR FISCAL IMPACT: None. 

 

IMPACT TO DISTRICT STAFFING: None. 

 

CONSULTATION WITH BOARD ADVISORY COMMITTEE: Not applicable.

 

BACKGROUND: The Regents of the University of California will provide the district with all planning, and implementation of tutoring support for students identified as refugee newcomer youth and identified youth experiencing homelessness participating in the districts Project RISE UP program.
 

Tutoring will be focused on offering supplemental English Language Development (ELD) instruction for newcomer refugee youth and youth experiencing homelessness at the elementary and middle school levels, to address academic gaps students are experiencing in school. Tutoring will also provide trauma informed support to address achievement gaps and increase the likelihood of improved attendance, mental health, self-sufficiency, and student participation.
 

Identified refugee newcomer youth is defined as: eligible school-aged newcomer students, ages five through 18, who arrived in the United States within the last five years, with the following immigration statuses: (1) refugees; (2) asylees; (3) Cuban and Haitian entrants; (4) Certain Amerasians from Vietnam; (5) victims of severe forms of trafficking who receive certification or an eligibility letter from the Office of Refugee Resettlement (ORR) and certain other specified family members of trafficking victims; (6) children classified as Special Immigrant Juveniles receiving services from ORR funded Unaccompanied Refugee Minor programs; and (7) Iraqi and Afghan children with Special Immigrant Visa status.
 

Eligible youth experiencing homelessness includes those youth in grades K-12 defined as homeless under the McKinney-Vento Act:

  • Children and youth who are sharing the housing of other persons due to loss of housing, economic hardship, or a similar reason;
  • Children and youth who may be living in motels, hotels, trailer parks, shelters;
  • Children and youth who have a primary nighttime residence that is a public or private place not designed for or ordinarily used as a regular sleeping accommodation for human beings;
  • Children and youth who are living in cars, parks, public spaces, abandoned buildings, substandard housing, bus or train stations, or similar settings; or 
  • Migratory children who qualify as homeless because they are children who are living in similar circumstances listed above.

 

[Originator/Contact: Nicole DeWitt, Executive Director, Leadership and Learning, 619.508.6632, ndewitt@sandi.net]

RECOMMENDATION: Ratify Agreement with San Diego County Superintendent of Schools, Promoting Achievement and Student Success (PASS) AmeriCorps Program to continue providing mentoring and prevention/intervention services to Kearny High School, Mann and Montgomery middle schools, and Rolando Park and Sherman Elementary Schools (PS22-0698-92). Authorize the execution of any documents necessary to effectuate this Agreement. The term of this Agreement is August 1, 2021 through June 30, 2022.

 

FISCAL IMPACT: Total not-to-exceed amount: $49,000.00; Budget Strings:

 

0259-09800-00-5801-1000-1110-01000-0000 Sherman Elementary (1 PASS AC $7,000.00)

0243-30106-00-5801-1000-1110-01000-0000 Rolando Park Elementary (1 PASS AC $7,000.00)

0316-00000-00-5853-1000-1110-01000-0000 Montgomery MS (1 PASS AC $7,000.00)

0312-30100-00-5853-1000-1110-01000-0000 Horace Mann MS (1 PASS AC $7,000.00)

0312-09800-00-5853-1000-1110-01000-0000 Horace Mann MS (Additional 1 PASS AC$7,000.00)

3733-09800-00-5853-2490-0000-01000-0000 Kearny High School (2 PASS AC $14,000.00)

(Splitting expenses evenly between four Kearny schools) (1 of 4)

3734-09800-00-5853-2490-0000-01000-0000 Kearny HighSchool (2 of 4)

3735-09800-00-5853-2490-0000-01000-0000 Kearny High School (3 of 4)

3736-09800-00-5853-2490-0000-01000-0000 Kearny High School (4 of 4)

 

PRIOR YEAR FISCAL IMPACT: For the period of August 1, 2020 through June 30, 2021: $49,000.00. 

 

IMPACT TO DISTRICT STAFFING: None. 

 

CONSULTATION WITH BOARD ADVISORY COMMITTEE: Not applicable.

 

BACKGROUND: The San Diego County of Superintendent of Schools PASS AmeriCorps Program provides mentoring and prevention/intervention services to students at the following district school sites: (1) Sherman Elementary, (2) Rolando Park Elementary, (3) Montgomery Middle School, (4) Horace Mann Middle School (two AmeriCorps Members), and (5) Kearny High School (two AmeriCorpsMembers) for a total of seven AmeriCorps Members.

 

PASS AmeriCorps Program is a civilian corps comprised of individuals whose goals are to service communities in support of the five promises to youth: (1) safe places; (2) healthy start of mind and body; (3) caring relationships with adults; (4) marketable skills; and (5) volunteer opportunities for youth in its schools and communities. PASS mentors are trained to provide services with the assistance of an on-site PASS support supervisor to ensure the program objectives are maintained and the experience is meaningful and productive. The San Diego County of Superintendent of Schools provides outreach hiring, training, support, and supervision of seven full-time PASS AmeriCorps staff in gang and violence prevention services; including support services for students/families. PASS AmeriCorpsvolunteers support district students at high-risk schools by helping them develop positive decision-making skills and strategies relating to healthy choices free of tobacco, drug, and gang violence. 

 

[Originator/Contact: Katherine Nelson, Executive Director, Leadership and Learning, 619.725.7772, knelson4@sandi.net]

RECOMMENDATION: Approve the Human Resource Services Division Recommendations for New and Revised Position Descriptions.

 

FISCAL IMPACT: Current budget covers any fiscal impact.

 

PRIOR YEAR FISCAL IMPACT: None. 

 

IMPACT TO DISTRICT STAFFING: None. The recommendations are an adjustment based on the current salary/pay additives of the incumbents in the classification.

As part of the districts obligation to maintain the classification plan and in response to requests from the bargaining units, management team, and recommendations from the joint labor-management Reclassification Committee, the Human Resource Services Division regularly provides recommendations for new and revised position descriptions. When applicable, and unless otherwise noted, the bargaining process has been completed for each position description presented in this item.

Information

Members of the public who desire to address the board on any topic related to board work, and not on today's regular meeting agenda, are welcome to do so at this time. Speakers are requested to:

  • limit their remarks to not more than 3 minutes;
  • appoint a spokesperson if the concern is a group concern; and,
  • supplement verbal presentation with written reports, if necessary or desired.
